PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WATSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 174 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully by showeth:
(1) That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only church built in Lithuania after World War II;
(2) This church was closed by the Soviet authorities on 15 August, 1960 and confiscated in 1961 under the direct order of Mr Khruschev.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs to raise with his counterpart in the USSR the great concern of many Australians that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the religious worshippers of Klaipeda in Lithuania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 84 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The students and staff of the University of Queensland express their dismay at the lack of adequate federal government funding to our University, which has resulted, inter alia, in the erosion of our Library facilities. We note that:
(1) The opening hours of our main Library have been reduced from 93 1/2 hours a week in 1975 to 72 hours a week in 1982.
(2) The number of new books purchased per year has fallen from over 50,000 in 1976 to under 23,000 in 1981.
(3) The number of books in storage and inaccessible to students and staff has risen from none in 1977 to over 40,000 in 1981.
(4) The number of books discarded in 1976 was over 6,000-by the end of 1981 over 70,000 had been discarded.

We believe this to be educationally retrograde and economically wasteful. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate urge the Government to increase funding to a level sufficient to allow the university to restore our previous library facilities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLLARD

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 23 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened:
Humbly Petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post.
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage.
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will.
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage.
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation.
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of: (i) intolerable behaviour; (ii) desertion for two years; and (iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that while generous tax concessions benefit established sectors of the now internationally acclaimed Australian film industry, other vital film activities, which are ineligible for tax concessions, have had to be severely curtailed due to the lack of funds available to the Creative Development Branch of the Australian Film Commission.

The Commission's Creative Development Branch is responsible for funding low budget films in order to develop new creative talent and ideas for the film industry to draw upon, it assists activities of major national significance such as the Australian Film Awards and the National Film Theatre, and it supports Film Festivals and film organisations in almost every state. All these aspects of the Commission's creative development work have suffered as the result of inflation eroding the Creative Development Branch's budget by over 40 per cent over the past five years.

Therefore your petitioners call upon the Federal Parliament to provide the Australian Film Commission with at least a 50 per cent increase in the budget for its Creative Development Branch in the coming financial year. This would be an essential first step towards ensuring the continuation of a viable and developing Australian film culture and film industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 310 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that-
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included in the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of the Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal elections on the question that:

'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The announcement was made last night so that the people of Australia would know what Telecom Australia, as a statutory body, was proposing in regard to telephone charges. The charge itself is determined by Telecom as a body and takes into account ordinary costs. As I recollect it, the Government received that recommendation within the last week and, having received it, approved it. —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of a report that Australian women do not have access to an improved rubella vaccine called Almevax? Is it a fact that if Almevax is to be used in vaccine programs it must be imported privately? Can the Minister confirm that the serum is being widely used in England and America in preference to the vaccine that we use in Australia? Can the Minister say whether the Government will review the stand that it has taken on this drug?

—I have a little information on this rubella vaccine. The vaccine to which Senator Walters referred, called Almevax, has been granted marketing approval in Australia by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. So it has marketing approval. Authority for the importation of Almevax has been given recently and it may be that the difficulties of the recent past to which Senator Walters referred may be overcome by this authority for importation. I am not able to confirm Senator Walters' statement about the use of the vaccine overseas because precise statistics are not available. We do know that both Almevax and the Cendehill strain vaccine, Cendevax, are widely used in England and the United States of America. Cendevax is the vaccine currently used in Australia so it is important to realise that there is a vaccine available and in use in this country at present. The rubella immunisation policy and the strain of vaccine to be used are currently being reviewed by a special working party of the National Health and Medical Research Council.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the figures used in the Budget Papers for the estimated expenditure this year on the unemployment benefit. Is it a fact that the Budget estimates that there will be an average of 395,000 people on the unemployment benefit in the coming financial year? Is it not a fact that in the month of July 405,000 people were on the unemployment benefit? Is it a fact that the Budget estimates that unemployment will increase, and increase considerably? Is it therefore a fact that the estimates in the Budget Papers are considerably low? Has the Minister any view on the accuracy of the figures that are used? Can he give us any idea of what the real figures will be?

—As was indicated I think by Senator Grimes in his own brief comments last night, the estimates contained in the Budget Papers are not estimates made by politicians based on what they would like the situation to be but rather are estimates made by the Treasury and other departments on the basis of the best information which is available to them. The figures which are included in the Budget with respect to estimates of the number unemployed and other relevant statistics have not been interfered with by me or any other Minister.
—They are fraudulent and you know it.

—This is not a matter which can be categorised as fraudulent, which I think was the word used by Senator Walsh. Of course, the Opposition would be the first to object if the Government chose the figures that it thought were satisfactory. In fact the figures are as we were advised of them when the Budget was being finalised. It is a fact that the figures for July show in excess of 400,000 unemployed. Those figures are subject to seasonal fluctuations . I will see whether there is a later estimate.
—The answer leaves much to be desired.

—The standard of both interjection and debate in this place leaves a great deal to be desired. The fact of the matter is that it is common knowledge in Australia, and ought to be common knowledge among honourable senators opposite, that there are seasonal fluctuations in unemployment figures. The sort of childish interjection which that statement gave rise to is pathetic.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. If the figures are seasonal, they are usually lowest in July. I ask the Minister: Is he telling us that the figures in the Budget are the figures of the Treasury, the figures of his Department or both?
—The figures are figures which, as I recall, were commented on by a number of departments but I think they are basically Treasury figures.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that in the 1981-82 financial year imports of cheese from the European Economic Community increased by 41.5 per cent compared with the previous year and that the majority of such cheese is dumped on to the Australian market with the help of EEC export subsidies which, for example, in the case of blue vein cheese amount to $941 per tonne? By comparison, the Australian tariff on blue vein cheese is a mere $96 per tonne. Does the Minister realise that the only Australian manufacturer of blue vein cheese, the Downs Co- operative Dairy Association Ltd in Toowoomba, Queensland, has ceased production of this cheese directly as a result of competition from subsidised EEC imports? What action is the Government contemplating to protect Australian cheese manufacturers from the dumping of EEC cheese onto the Australian market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the fact that there has been an increase in the importation of cheese and it is also aware of the concern which has been expressed by certain parts of the Australian dairy industry at the rapid growth in imports. There was a claim that European cheeses were being sold in Australia at dumped or subsidised prices, and the Minister for Primary Industry pointed out to the industry the remedies available under the Customs anti-dumping legislation. Following that, the industry has now filed a dumping complaint against imports of blue vein cheese from Denmark. Of course, that is the appropriate action to be taken in cases of the sort outlined by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. The Government would expect the action to resolve whether blue vein cheese is in fact being sold at dumped or subsidised prices and whether that action is causing any injury to the Australian industry.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been an increase in the number of complaints about dumping generally, not merely in this area. The procedure which is available to any industry which believes it is being damaged is that it may lodge a complaint. Investigations are then carried out in Australia and overseas and there is a meeting of parties at which opposing statements can be tested in the open. This ensures that any decision which has to be taken by the Minister to protect the local industry is based on facts and not merely on allegations. At the moment there are 63 cases in hand, which is nearly double the number of a year ago. The Minister is watching this situation very carefully as it is obviously a growing problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, relates to the many chronically ill people in the community who are not pensioners entitled to free pharmaceuticals and who do not qualify for the new $2 concession because their income is not low enough. The groups that have been receiving their medication free of charge will continue to receive their medication free of charge under the Pensioner Health Scheme or under the Repatriation Benefits Scheme. The new group that will be introduced has been identified as a group in financial need.

ANSWER.PARA: I put to Senator Haines that there is a difficult choice involved. Either we try to identify families in financial need or we try a different approach, as Senator Haines has suggested, and look at groups with a particular medical need. It may be particularly complicated to take the road that she has suggested. The Government, in attempting to respond to those with particular financial needs, has gone down one road to increase social equity and to try to relieve the burden on many groups. The honourable senator is correct that the rest of us will have to pay an increased price per prescription and that, therefore, for those people who need a large number of prescriptions an extra charge will be involved. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the announcement in last night's Budget of quite a substantial reduction in income tax collections. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: THIRD ANGLICAN GRAMMAR SCHOOL

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education aware of the remarks of the Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, Dr Richard Campbell, reported in today's Canberra Times, relating to any proposal to establish a third Anglican grammar school in the Australian Capital Territory? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see this morning's article. Indeed, I am aware of considerable interest in the Australian Capital Territory concerning the question of the establishment of a third Anglican grammar school. Honourable senators will be aware that last night I announced that the Government did intend to give financial support to the establishment of a third Anglican grammar school. I announced then the amounts of support which would be available . In fact, there has been quite extensive consultation with the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. This is the Authority which operates the government school system in the Australian Capital Territory. I have received and considered written views from the Authority. I have met with the Chairman and the Chief Education Officer. I have received and considered a written report from the Authority entitled 'Impact of the third grammar school on enrolments in the Government school system'. ANSWER.PARA: The third Anglican grammar school has aroused strong passions. TALK.START.PARA: — The announcement does mean that a group tax return can be lodged, but the new measure will apply only for losses that have been incurred in or after the 1982-83 income tax year. This will prevent any trafficking in past year losses. There will be a requirement that there be a 100 per cent common ownership of the companies involved. The provision for this group tax return is welcomed, but there is the requirement that it be effective only from the 1982-83 year.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In 1975-76, that is, the year of the last Labor Government Budget, pay- as-you-earn taxpayers paid 59.3 per cent of income tax, including company tax. In 1981-82, that figure had risen to 65.8 per cent and from the estimate in last night's Budget of tax revenue in the current year it will rise to 66.4 per cent. I ask: If the self-employed professional speculators who have been dodging tax and other non-PAYE taxpayers had been required to pay the same proportion this year and last year as they paid in 1975-76, would wage and salary earners, that is PAYE taxpayers, have paid $1,700m less tax last year and $2,000m less this year for the same total revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the precise amount that might have been paid by way of relief to PAYE taxpayers if those who have been avoiding tax had been capable of being compelled to pay tax. It is a notorious fact that there has been, over the last decade, a growth of the tax avoidance industry in Australia at both ends of the tax scale. I refer to two areas-the cash payments situation, where a great number of people avoid tax by cash payments and at the other end people avoiding company tax and their own personal tax. It is because of that trend that this Government, unlike its predecessor, has acted very vigorously indeed in a considerable number of ways to stamp out tax avoidance. In fact the Budget is able to report that the Commissioner of Taxation says that the revenue that will flow this year will show positive proof that those anti- tax-avoidance schemes are working.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government proposes to bring down very significant legislation in addition to the great volume of actions it has taken in the past to make sure that tax avoiders do not in future impose burdens on PAYE taxpayers. I repeat that the Government is very well aware that ordinary wage and salary earners have been, over the past decade, paying a greater proportion of tax than their due, largely and significantly because of tax avoidance. The anti-tax-avoidance measures that the Government is taking and has taken, plus the announcements of new tax collection methods to be adopted in future years, will, in the view of the Government and indeed in the estimate of the Commissioner of Taxation, go a considerable way towards obviating that. It is a great joy to the Government that it has been able in this Budget to announce significant tax concessions to the taxpayers of Australia, particularly the low wage and salary earners. I think the Budget last night was able to say that now 75 per cent of all taxpayers would be in the standard tax rate and that that tax rate would be reduced to 30c in the dollar. That is quite a considerable achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer once again to the size of coinage and notes which are used within Australia. I ask: As our coinage sizes seem to have followed the size of coins in the United Kingdom, is the Minister aware that a small multi-sided coin , with a value approximating 40c, has been issued in England as a part of England's remodelling of all its coinage? Will the Australian Government once again look at the whole matter of the out of date size of our notes and coins and also consider introducing coins of much higher value than we have at present , up to, say, $2 or $5, money that would be useful in many coin operated machines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I undertake to refer that matter to the Treasurer for his consideration.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the person who is now head of the new Tasmanian Liberal Premier's office, Mr Andrew Tilt, was fined in the Hobart magistrates' court this week for failing to lodge a tax return for 1980-81, during which period he was employed on the staff of a Minister of this Federal Government, namely, the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman? Is it also a fact that Mr Tilt had previous convictions for failure to lodge tax returns and failure to comply with orders made under the Income Tax Assessment Act? Was he originally to be employed as head of the Premier's office under a tax avoiding arrangement whereby his salary would be paid to his company rather than to him? Was such an arrangement the method by which he was paid during his employment until May this year as Principal Private Secretary to the Minister for Administrative Services, or at any time was he paid other than by normal salary in his personal capacity? Finally, were or are any other staff members of Ministers of this Government paid other than by normal salary or would such tax avoiding activities and non- lodgement of tax returns be approved by the Government or by any Minister of it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information regarding the gentleman or his previous activities. I will seek that from the relevant Minister. I will also seek confirmation of whether other people have had particular arrangements regarding their employment. If I receive relevant information I will let Senator Coates know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer him to an article which appeared in the National Times of 17 June and which relates to a speech by Mr Alan Asher, the editor of Choice magazine, delivered at the 1982 Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference, on the influence of massive media campaigns aimed at luring consumers away from fresh farm produce towards heavily processed and value added convenience foods. Will the Minister comment on this article and in particular on this disturbing claim by Mr Asher:

QUESTION.PARA: More than three-quarters of this advertising by the food industry was found by the Australian Consumers Association to contravene the Commonwealth Government's health objectives, and that 90 per cent of television advertisements screened during children's watching time promoted foods unsound from a dietary and health viewpoint.

In view of the large number of food makers operating allegedly in direct conflict with the Government's national diet goals set out by the Department of Health in 1979, I ask the Minister: First, what action will be taken by the Government to ensure that food advertisements, especially those directed to young children, will encourage safe and healthy eating practices? Secondly, will consideration be given by the Government to the call of the Australian Consumers Association for a code of practice based on the Government's national diet goals to be enforced on all food advertisers in television, radio and the Press, as one way of achieving a better national food standard and diet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article written by Mr Asher and of the study carried out by the Australian Consumers Association. Interestingly, similar studies have been carried out overseas. The figures produced by Mr Asher from the survey to which he referred show higher figures-that is, I take it, a worse performance-than those shown in overseas surveys. There is a need then for some examination to try to work out why these differences occur and whether there is something peculiar to Australian practice. I am not able to give Senator Missen details of what was actually in the media campaign or whether it has the qualities which he ascribes to it. I am aware that the National Health and Medical Research Council has been concerned about the health implications of television food advertisements. It does have a working party which is considering this and related matters. It has been looking at television advertisements of foods directed at children. The recommendations of that working party are before the Department of Health at present. I take it that there will be some decision by the Department of Health which may lead to some action by it.

ANSWER.PARA: In the meantime, discussions are under way between the National Health and Medical Research Council and the food industry in Australia. There is an attempt , through a new sub-committee on nutritional education, to develop a set of guidelines and that sub-committee will actually involve the food industry as well as health authorities. So Senator Missen will probably be encouraged, as I am, by the fact that some co-operative action is going ahead to try to work out what is appropriate advertising. But I would say again that there are recommendations before the Department of Health in relation to the matters he raised on which decisions are still awaited.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen a recent report in the British Medical Journal that smoking is beneficial to health? Two research doctors claim that taking up smoking 'magically charmed away a patient's ulcerative colitis'. When doctors persuaded the patient to give up smoking, the illness flared up again. Is the Minister also aware that there has been only one randomised test on the effects of smoking-that of Rose and Hamilton-which concluded that there was no evidence of any reduction in mortality among men who gave up smoking? Indeed, the mortality rate was far greater than among men who continued to smoke. What is the Government's response to these assertions, and will the Government consider a reduction in excise on cigarettes and tobacco, especially for Australian working men and women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the end of his question Senator Elstob referred to the Government's policy position. That position is well known. The Government's policy, as has been stated, seeks to encourage a diminution in the rate of smoking in this country. That was a recommendation which it took up from a committee of the Senate. The honourable senator referred to the very serious disease ulcerative colitis. I can remember that a text book published in 1940, which I looked at for historical interest, recommended that enemas of tannic acid were good for ulcerative colitis. I would imagine that that was probably highly dangerous for the patients. I am interested now that Senator Elstob brings in further antediluvian treatments, saying that smoking is good for ulcerative colitis. It so happens that in the specialty which I practised before coming into this place ulcerative colitis was one of the most serious illnesses. Whatever else does cure it, cigarette smoking does not.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Elstob would know of the quite classical work of Richard Doll and his colleagues using cohorts of doctors as subjects which proves, I think quite clearly and statistically, that when those doctors altered their smoking practice their health status improved. Smoking is an individual question for people. We are not out to be proscriptive, but I am quite alarmed when the article in the British Medical Journal, which no doubt was published to promote scientific argument and discourse, is quoted as if it is so authoritative that all the other evidence which exists should be set aside. Smoking is harmful to health, a diminution of smoking is good for the community, and smoking still represents the greatest single preventable health hazard facing Australia today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps Senator Baume-he is a much younger man than I-would like to engage in a contest of our physical fitness. I have smoked since I was 12 years of age. I smoke 40 to 50 cigarettes a day. I challenge Senator Baume to a contest of fitness. He might like to be in that.
—Order! I do not accept that as a supplementary question but rather as an interesting comment and challenge. However, if the Minister wishes to respond, he may.
—Mr President, I will contest the honourable senator at Question Time because that is an arena in which I can best him. I will not give him a physical contest because I could not hope to beat him.

—I refer Senator Sir John Carrick to the 1982-83 Budget provision of a grant of $8.3m towards the cost of a new coal-fired power station in Darwin. Having in mind the discussions which have taken place between the Federal and Northern Territory governments for a considerable time now, is the Minister in a position to indicate details of the agreement reached between the two parties and the effects the rising cost of electricity will have on the overall project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For quite some months discussions have gone on between the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government, in which I participated, with the objective of replacing the existing oil fired power station at Stokes Hill with a coal fired installation. The present installation is grossly inefficient and of course in the long term will depend upon a fuel which is subject to sharply rising costs. I am happy to say that the two governments have reached full agreement and that the Northern Territory Government has expressed itself as very happy with the arrangements we have made . The effect is that in this Budget there will be a grant of $8.3m towards the cost of work in this year on the construction of a new coal fired power station at a site on Channel Island about 10 kilometres from Darwin. It is envisaged that the Commonwealth assistance will amount to about $124m at 1980-81 prices out of a total estimated capital cost of $310m for the new station. That is a very significant Commonwealth contribution.

ANSWER.PARA: The Budget this year also provides $56m for implementing an agreed formula for assistance towards the operational costs of the Northern Territory Electricity Commission. It includes a load growth factor of 5 per cent and the sharing between the two parties of load growth beyond that level. The formula also includes an agreed basis for calculating the movement of costs over the five- year period for the purpose of determining the level of assistance. The formula envisages that the tariff in the Northern Territory should be similar to the tariff in north Queensland. Knowing the difficulties of the Northern Territory, a reasonable comparison has been made. The formula therefore will give not only assistance by way of capital costs to build the station but also a long term formula of subsidy in the operation of the station. The Government appreciates the difficulties of the Northern Territory with vast distances, remoteness, difficulties in hauling the fuel and a relatively sparse population. I repeat that the Northern Territory Government has expressed great satisfaction with the arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to the Budget statement that the Government has decided to write off the meat industry's debt of $23.5m on the tuberculosis and brucellosis eradication campaign increase and at the same time to increase by 33 1/3 per cent the industry levy so as to collect $24.5m. Does the Government not consider that this savage increase will further erode the possibility of marginal pastoral properties from continuing in the campaign? Will the Government consider fully funding the eradication campaign to ensure its effectiveness?

—It is very common for campaigns of this sort to be funded by industry with some contribution by government. I think the Government would be reluctant to undertake a course of conduct with this industry or any other industry which involved it in providing the total cost of disease control programs. Whilst I will refer the question to the Minister for Primary Industry for his consideration, I think I can on his behalf express doubt that that would be seen as a very sensible course of action. The write-off related to the difficult period that the industry has been through. It was thought by the Government that that was a constructive contribution to make at the time when it was setting a future course for the conduct of that campaign. I will seek a more detailed response from the Minister for Primary Industry, but I think the Government saw that simply as a positive contribution to an industry which has been in considerable difficulty and which has continuing difficulties. I do not believe the Government would see it as a reason for undertaking the total cost of what is really part of the cost of production in that industry.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask: Given statements made in the United States at the recent launching of the Trident submarine, will the Minister advise whether plans for Western Australia's HMAS Stirling naval base include its intended use as an operating base for this latest diabolical nuclear machine? Will he also advise whether an approach has been made by the United States Government to the Australian Government to have the facility used for that purpose?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence and ask for an early answer.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction. In the investigations into the replacement of the vessel Empress of Australia with appropriate shipping for the Bass Strait run, what steps have been taken to ascertain from the users of the service the basic requirements of this trade in relation both to passengers and freight? Will the prime consideration for the ultimate choice of vessel or vessels be their optimum appropriateness to the users for this multi-faceted task?

—Over a period a number of studies have been undertaken to consider the need for sea passenger services for Tasmania. I think Senator Archer in particular will be aware of those studies. The last two studies of significance were the Bureau of Transport Economics' report entitled 'Demand for Sea Transport between Tasmania and the Australian Mainland', which was issued in 1980, and the report of the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania, which was presented last year. The Minister expects shipowners to undertake independently any further study of Tasmania's needs necessary for preparing statements of interest in response to the invitation from the Minister on that point. Statements of interest have been requested to be submitted by the end of this month. Honourable senators can be assured that it is the Government's intention that the service should meet Tasmania's requirements in all respects. I am also certain that the Minister, when decisions are finally taken, will say that the service should be established on a commercially viable basis.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer with a brief reference to the editorial which appeared in today's Australian Financial Review entitled 'Stand By for the Depression', in which it is pointed out that Australia will be lucky to see a rate of unemployment of less than 10 per cent by the end of this financial year, with an even higher rate of unemployment being a distinct possibility. As the 1982-83 Budget guarantees that the economic costs of the recession will now be concentrated on the ranks of the unemployed, boosted enormously and unevenly by mass retrenchments, will the Australian Bureau of Statistics adopt a new set of guidelines to determine the actual number of unemployed persons in Australia, thereby replacing the hopelessly inadequate and inaccurate method of random sampling currently in use, to enable the Australian people and this Parliament to monitor accurately what this Government has turned into Australia's major social crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will ignore some of the comments that were made in the question. The methods used by the Bureau of Statistics are its own methods and have been devised by the Bureau to collect the statistics and to deal with the statistics which are collected throughout Australia. They are made available for use by the Australian Government and others who wish to be informed on many aspects of statistical material. I am not aware of any change the Bureau envisages in the collection, compilation and expression of figures relating to those people who are unemployed. If the Bureau of Statistics has any changes in mind I will see that Senator Jones is advised.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to the announcement that multicultural television will be coming to this area.
—Here we go again.

—Senator Grimes said: 'Here we go again'. I am glad that the proceedings of the Senate are being broadcast, Mr President. It is most appropriate that the people of Canberra should know what the Australian Labor Party really thinks about issues that are of relevance to this area. I refer to the number of people who, in recent years, have made extensive outlays on television sets with no ultra high frequency tuner. Will the Minister give consideration to the possibility of providing multicultural television in this region on the very high frequency band?

—I think all honourable senators will welcome the Government' s announcement that multicultural television will come to the national capital and will be introduced progressively in a number of cities. I must say that, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications in this place, I have had a number of representations from Senator Reid on behalf of her constituents and I am grateful for the interest she has taken in this matter over a considerable time. What Senator Reid says is correct, namely, that a number of people, particularly those of limited means, have television sets which do not have a UHF capacity; and expense in replacing their present sets would be involved for some, who depend on television for contact with the world outside. The Department of Communications has advised the Minister that there are in the Australian Capital Territory no VHF channels which are readily available for the purpose she seeks. Because the provision of any such VHF channel would involve the displacement of another channel it may be difficult to do exactly what Senator Reid is suggesting. Any VHF channel that was chosen for multicultural television in Canberra would involve making changes to existing commercial and national translators in the region. Therefore, there is some difficulty in taking the course that the honourable senator seeks. However, I believe the Minister would want to know of her concern that some of her constituents may find difficulty in getting access to the programs because of this reception problem and I will undertake to pass the matter on to him for his attention.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INTEREST RATES: EFFECT OF BUDGET DEFICIT

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to an answer that he gave to one of my questions in this chamber in February this year in which he said that income tax cuts could only be made if the Budget deficit was substantially increased or expenditure was cut to the tune of $500m to $700m. He went on to say that such increases in the deficit would force up interest rates to the detriment of home buyers. Does the Minister still believe that such increases in the deficit force up interest rates? Further, if he believes that an increase of $700m in the Budget deficit would force up interest rates, what sort of increase in interest rates does he expect from a Budget deficit of $1, 600m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My recollection of the details of the answer is not clear but, certainly, any very substantial increase in a deficit would force up interest rates. I do not think there is any doubt about that. I wonder whether Senator Foreman would disagree with the following statement:

ANSWER.PARA: Some might argue that a large deficit could be offset by a tough monetary policy -but this would mean greatly increased interest rates, disruption in financial markets, further depression of business confidence and serious company failures. That is an unacceptable option.

I should tell Senator Foreman before he objects that that is Mr Hayden's statement. So that, in point of fact, what I said regarding dimensions-I referred to a very large deficit-is quite clearly supported by his own leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I refer to the latter part of my question, in which I asked: If the Minister believes that an increase of $700m in the Budget deficit would force up interest rates, what sort of increase in interest rates does he expect from a Budget deficit of $1,600m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The increase in the deficit is not $1,700m but rather some $1,200m. A $700m cut in revenue in order to provide income tax cuts would provide less than half, perhaps less than a third, of the income tax relief that the Government has extended in this year's Budget; it would give a very small cut indeed. I believe that a reduction of one cent in the 32c rate which operates at the tax threshold represents a loss in revenue of about $600m. That does not take into consideration the other cuts that have been made. My argument has always been that any substantial increase in the deficit would have the effects described. Indeed, Mr Hayden underlined the fact that he was talking of substantial deficits. I remain of that view also.

—I preface my question, which is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, by referring to the commendable initiative taken by the Government last night in allocating over $1m for the further development of the SYNROC technique, which was originally developed by Dr A. E. Ringwood of the Australian National University, in order to enable the construction by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission of a pilot plant to produce full-size canisters of SYNROC. Am I correct in recalling that some time ago the Minister stated that Australia was not going to store nuclear waste in this country? If so, does this initiative not indicate Australia's willingness to adopt an international role in ensuring that everything possible is done, scientifically and technically, to find the safest way of storing those wastes? Can the Minister elaborate on the potential for offering economic advantages relating to SYNROC, as was pointed out last night in the Budget document?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first say that it is emphatically not the intention of this Government to offer any facilities to store in Australia the nuclear wastes of other countries.
—Why not?

—Perhaps, if Senator Walsh wants to do so, he might indicate his desire. The fact is that there is, and necessarily will be, great development in the world of the use of nuclear power for electric power generation. As a result, there will be in other countries the generation of considerable wastes and a need for its safe and safer storage. A borosilicate, which is a form of glass, is already used for containing and storing nuclear waste. It is believed to be highly stable and successful. Indeed, in a number of countries such waste is now embodied and stored in borosilicate glass.

ANSWER.PARA: In Australia, Professor Ringwood of the Australian National University, as a result of research, asserts-and in this is supported by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission-that his product, SYNROC, will be even better than borosilicate glass in achieving these ends. SYNROC, or synthetic rock, is a stable combination of minerals similar to naturally occurring rocks which have immobilised radioactive elements in the earth's crust for millions of years. In other words, it is similar, even identical, to rocks which we know have been absolutely stable for millions of years even in unstable circumstances and which have impounded and contained radioactivity. The aim is to develop such a synthetic rock to contain wastes. It is understood that it would have a great advantage, namely that it would not be necessary to store it for 20 or 30 years as one must do with borosilicate glass for cooling purposes, but that, after being produced, it could be placed in the ground in inert areas such as salt mines in particular. It is strongly believed that it would be inert for millions of years. So the Government has put aside slightly more than $1m for research into this matter. It is one of the great opportunities Australia has to help the outside world with one of its major problems. I think all Australians would commend it. I repeat: We say this against the necessity for the outside world to use more and more uranium and therefore to produce more and more nuclear waste. That is unarguable. Therefore, I take it that everybody wants Australian research to be so pursued that we are able to offer to the world something that will add to the safety, security and health not only of this generation but of the generations of the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Has the Minister read the comments in the Australian Conservation Foundation newsletter of Dr Mosley which question the efficiency of our national kangaroo management program? Does the Federal Minister intend having a summit meeting with the State Ministers for Wildlife and Conservation to remedy these deficiencies?

— I am aware of the comments made by Dr Mosley in the newsletter of the Australian Conservation Foundation, I think in the August 1982 issue, concerning the national kangaroo management program. At a meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers in June 1982, which involves the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory, a review of the national kangaroo management program was initiated, so action is underway. The review is being carried out by a working group of wildlife officers and the results of that review will be considerd by the Ministers at the next meeting of the Council in mid-1983. I think Senator Mulvihill would agree that although the working group has been commissioned it does require some time to do this work and to bring its findings together. So the concern which he expressed is already being responded to by way of action: There is a working group in progress and there will be a report by mid-1983.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Following the survey will there be revision of any of the States' culling targets? Will they wait to see the outcome of the survey? I would like to have an assurance that there will be no change in the States' culling targets until this survey is completed.

—I will refer that question to the Minister whom I represent , but on the information I have here it would appear that there will be no change. To be quite certain, I will refer it to the Minister for a detailed answer.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's continuing failure to take effective action against tax cheats and the oppressive burden this has placed on honest PAYE and other taxpayers.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Fraser Government took office in 1975 there has been a progressive shift of the taxation burden onto pay-as- you-earn taxpayers, or wage and salary earners from non-PAYE taxpayers. In 1975- 76, the year of the last Labor Budget, 59.3 per cent of income tax, including company tax, was paid by PAYE taxpayers. By 1981-82 that percentage had risen to 65.8 per cent. If the non-PAYE taxpayers-that is, the Pitt Street farmers who dominate the Fraser Cabinet, self-employed professionals, speculators and others including those who are in proprietary companies-had paid the same share of tax last year as they paid in 1975-76, wage and salary earners would have paid $1, 700m less. If anyone thinks that that is trivial, or if any honourable senator on the Government side suggests that it is trivial, I remind them that that is more than taxpayers will gain in total as a result of the changes to the taxation schedule announced last night-which amounts, of course, to no more than indexation.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1982-83 Budget has not arrested that trend, much less reversed the drift. On the current year's income, excluding the wildcat estimates and illogical figures on recoveries from past years which have been fabricated for the purposes of the 1982 Budget, the proportion of tax paid by PAYE taxpayers will rise from 65.8 per cent to 66.4 per cent. So if the same contributions had been made in 1982-83 as were made in 1975-76, wage and salary earners would be paying $2,000m less tax this year than it is estimated they will pay. That massive shift is partly due to deliberate Government action, through writing concessions into the Income Tax Assessment Act and opening up loopholes pursuant to those concessions, but it is mostly due to tax cheating, tax dodging, tax avoidance or whatever one likes to call it-the anti-social activity which Senator Withers assured us at the end of last month is indulged in by most of his colleagues.

This benign government attitude to the social cancer of tax evasion and the huge leakage of revenue which it entails will surprise those who are not familiar with the ethos and structure of the Liberal Party of Australia and the culpable negligence of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). On 27 June this year the Treasurer made a statement, belatedly wrung out of him by the embarrassing disclosures of the McCabe-Lafranchi report. In that statement the Treasurer admitted to having been told as early as May 1978 about so-called bottom-of-the- harbour schemes and the prospect of criminal prosecutions being launched. Of course he did have decisive evidence, as was shown in the House of Representatives yesterday and will be shown again by subsequent speakers in this debate, that there was scope from criminal prosecution long before 1978. But he admitted at the end of June that he was advised by the Australian Taxation Office that these schemes were in operation and that there was a possibility of criminal prosecution. Two and a half years later he got around to taking legislative action. More than four years later, after the disclosures of McCabe- Lafranchi, he threatened, and he continues to threaten, retrospective action. His 27 June statement should be regarded as as much an apologia for failure as was his Budget Speech last night. It was also a confession of what is at best negligence and what could conceivably be much worse. His excuse for not acting when he himself admits he became aware of these schemes in 1978, as put in his Press release of 27 June, was:
. . . public attitudes against tax avoidance were only in their formative stages at the time the schemes described in the Report were reaching their peak in 1977 and 1978. . .
In other words, what this wretched creature was saying on 27 June was that he took no action because the public was not-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, you used the words 'wretched creature'. Were you referring to the Federal Treasurer?
—I was indeed.
—I ask for an immediate unconditional withdrawal.
—I withdraw.
—Unconditionally, Senator.
—I withdraw. This pathetic creature-
—Senator Walsh, I warn you to stay within the confines of parliamentary language. You know Standing Order 418.
—I accept your judgment on that, Mr President. What this creature was saying in his 27 June statement was that he took no action because the public was not angry--
—Order, Senator! Are you again referring to the Federal Treasurer?
—As a creature?
—Yes.
—Yes.
—Withdraw it.

—Very well, I withdraw. What am I allowed to call him-Mr Howard? Mr Howard was saying in his 27 June statement that he took no action because the public was not angry enough. The public did not know but Mr Howard did. When action, or the promise of action, finally appeared from the Treasurer it was prompted not by moral outrage but by fear of electoral retribution flowing from the disclosures of the McCabe-Lafranchi report-retribution from the millions of honest pay-as-you-earn and other taxpayers whose earnings have been filched for half a decade by tax cheats with the full knowledge of the Treasurer and the Government of Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —Who was in charge of the Senate?

SPEECH.PARA: All the evidence is that the persistent attack on tax avoidance by legislation in recent years, particularly the introduction of the new general anti-tax avoidance provisions of Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, has had a signal impact on tax avoidance. Scheme promoters have publicly stated that tax avoidance is now dead. Their view is largely supported by comments from responsible practitioners also. For example, in a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald recently, Mr Roderick C. Cameron, the national chairman of one of Australia's largest accounting firms, stated:

Tax avoidance is now dead. I refer to avoidance (use of artificial schemes) as distinct from evasion (the cash economy). When are the media going to give due recognition to the achievements of the Treasurer, Mr Howard, in relation to tax avoidance?
Mr Cameron went on:
There continues to be widespread coverage of the avoidance of huge sums of taxation in past years in such a way that the public must believe that a major problem still exists.
Mr Cameron continued:

Extensive coverage given recently to the rather emotive remarks of Mr John Miller, the president of the Australian Society of Accountants, would have added further to that impression. The fact is that tax avoidance is finished. Mr Howard has had to overcome enormous problems, particularly those arising from certain High Court decisions in years past. The war has been won by the Treasurer and the public should be left in no doubt of it. Mr Howard deserves the highest praise.

As a result of advice received from the Commissioner of Taxation, the Government has for the first time in several years made no allowance in this year's Budget estimates for leakage of tax revenue through tax avoidance. There should in fact be a substantial contribution to the revenue in 1982-83 as a result of this collection of unpaid tax in tax avoidance cases as a result of the Government's action in doubling the rate of late payment penalties and other measures that were announced on 10 August.

With regard to action against tax evasion, three matters are relevant. Firstly, the Government acted in 1980 to make the evasion of company tax through so- called bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion schemes a criminal offence punishable by a fine of up to $50,000, or five years imprisonment, or both. Secondly, the Government announced on 25 July legislative measures to obtain from vendor shareholders payment of unpaid company tax from bottom-of-the-harbour strips of pre-tax company profits. In his Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that these measures would be extended to include recovery of evaded Division 7 tax on undistributed company profits. Thirdly, on the subject of evasion through the cash economy, the Treasurer announced in his Budget Speech details of a deduction-at-source system to operate from 1 July 1983 for payments for labour and services which are not currently subject to the pay-as-you-earn system.

Later I will seek leave to table a summary of anti-tax avoidance legislation enacted since 1 July 1977. This details a very large volume of legislation which has been introduced by the Government in recent years to counter specific tax avoidance arrangements. The list includes the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Act (No. 2) of 1977, which dealt with deceased estates and companies; an amendment Act of 1978 dealing with bonus shares, trading stock schemes, tax rebates in respect of dividends which arose from modified dividend stripping, the denial of a deduction for gifts made under certain arrangements, and so on; the Sales Tax Assessment Amendment Acts of 1978; the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Act of 1978; a further Act in 1979; that is, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Act (No. 4); the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Act (No. 5) 1979; the Income Tax Laws Amendment Act 1979 related to sections 56, 59, 59AA and 62. I could go on to 1980, when amendments were made which very effectively deal with many of the matters which have been the subject of some concern. Going to 1981, there are pages and pages of amendments that have been introduced directly by the present Treasurer to deal with many of the matters about which we are speaking today in this matter of public importance.

In concentrating on the more sophisticated schemes, the media have perhaps not given sufficient attention to the enormous losses to revenue which can occur through the so-called cash economy. In this and in the Budget of last night the Government has given careful consideration to the most effective and appropriate way to deal with this matter. It has consulted industry representatives and organisations and has analysed methods adopted in other countries. The measures introduced in the Budget are aimed to catch those people who are not declaring income that consists of payments for labour and services. This system will be the subject of further consultation. By the time it is put into effect I am sure it also will be an effective scheme that will collect for the Commonwealth revenue a large amount that has been uncollectable because no system was in place to deal with this aspect. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that something like $500m a year could be expected to be raised as a result of dealing with the cash economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —An admission of failure by your Government.

— No, it is an omission of a PAYE system which did not deal with those who did not declare their income. It is a matter now of taxing at source payments made for labour and services that previously had not been part of a PAYE system through a person's employer. I believe it will be a very effective measure. It will deal with something that has been an important part of avoidance of the payment of tax. The Treasurer has stated that this new system will be seen as protecting contractors, the vast bulk of whom are honest, from unfair competition from those who are currently evading tax.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the measures I have detailed that have been the subject of legislation, set out in the summary which I will table, the Government has also introduced a package of general measures which are designed to foil arrangements which have the purpose or effect of avoiding Australian income tax. The first part of this package-the general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act-is a most significant and far reaching measure. Another key feature of the legislation is the statutory imposition of additional tax equal to double the tax sought to be avoided on tax payers whose schemes are struck down by Part IVA. As I said earlier, it is because of this Government's active campaign against tax avoidance and the publicity it has attracted that the average Australian has become aware of the extent of the practice. This Government has done more to fight tax avoidance than any other government that has had to deal with matters of this kind.

At Question Time today Senator Evans mentioned some statements that were made earlier. A number of statements have been made on the subject dealing with the advice that was available to the Government at various times. I wish to refer to the statement made by the Treasurer on 27 June of this year dealing with the McCabe-Lafranchi report, which was the result of the Victorian Government's inquiry into related matters. On page 12 of that statement the Treasurer noted:

In addition, in August-September 1974, the Commissioner, through his Deputy, sought legal advice from the local Deputy Crown Solicitor as to whether the facts available would support a prosecution against any person under income tax legislation, the Commonwealth Crimes Act or the Companies Act.

The Deputy Commissioner received this opinion in January 1975, and it was to the effect that on the material presented by the Commissioner to counsel, grounds existed for prosecution under Section 67 of the Companies Act and under Section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act and that proceedings could be instituted under Section 367B of the Companies Act.
On page 13 of that statement the Treasurer noted:

Discussions and correspondence ensued and in April 1979 the Commissioner received Crown Law advice to the effect that there was insufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case of 'conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth'

That was part of the statement made by the Treasurer on 27 June. In his statement of 25 July headed 'Recovery of tax evaded in schemes to strip companies of untaxed profits' he referred to new legal advice on action against promoters. On page 3 of that statement he noted:

The Solicitor-General has now advised, in relation to a particular case, that action is available primarily against people other that the vendor shareholders under Commonwealth and State laws that offer avenues for recovery through procedures under the Companies Act whereby funds could be restored to the stripped company to enable it to meet the as yet unsatisfied income tax assessments that had been raised on it.

The statement goes on with further comment. A further statement issued on 17 August by the Treasurer headed 'Recovery of Division 7 tax evaded in company strips' shows a further determination of the Commonwealth to deal with tax that has been evaded in these matters.

I believe that all the matters to which I am referring concerning the whole principle of tax avoidance show the determination of the Treasurer to do whatever is needed by legislation to assist the Commissioner of Taxation to collect tax. It ought to be remembered, as was stated by the Commissioner of Taxation yesterday, that the first and most important point to be made is that the revenue involved in such schemes has not been lost. The announcement by the Treasurer on 25 July that legislative measures would be introduced to obtain payment from vendor shareholders of unpaid company tax from these strips indicated that a substantial amount of the $500m-odd attributable to such activities prior to the introduction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 would be recovered in 1982-83. I repeat that the Commissioner of Taxation says this revenue has not been lost. It will be recovered; it will be pursued.

The second point made by the Commissioner is that the Government has introduced legislation in the form of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 to make a specific criminal offence the kind of activity to which the McCabe-Lafranchi report drew attention. That legislation was introduced and passed through the Parliament in 1980. Since that Act was passed only isolated instances have been uncovered of continuing activity of this kind. Those cases are being actively investigated to gather sufficient evidence on which to bring criminal prosecutions and to expose participants in the courts. The Australian Taxation Office is continuing to raise assessments against companies that had been stripped before the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act commenced to operate. That action is moving ahead in a co-ordinated way to ensure that earliest effect is given to recovery of tax under the measures announced on 25 July. On an associated front, in light of the Solicitor-General's recent opinion, action is being taken to bring before the courts promoters and their associates under provisions of company law and criminal law.

By what I have said in detailing and outlining the statements that have been made by the Treasurer, and which are available for reading, I think it can accurately be shown that a consistent and persistent effort has been made by this Government to pursue those people who have been avoiding their responsibilities in the payment of tax that was rightly a debt to the Commonwealth. I would suggest that if we were to look seriously at what has been achieved and the way in which we have harnessed community opinion to support the Government in these measures, it ought to be said that the Treasurer, John Howard, deserves the praise of the community for his relentless approach to collecting the proper share and burden of tax throughout the community.

I conclude by saying what I think the Treasurer said today in answer to a question. He was asked whether there was continuing concern in the community about tax avoidance, despite the Government's legislative program directed against it. He was also asked to what extent the legislation is proving effective in containing tax avoidance. He said:

I think probably the two most contemporary and best pieces of evidence of the success of the Government's campaign in this area are, firstly, the fact that I was advised by the Australian Taxation Office that it would not be necessary this year to make a downward adjustment in the revenue figures on account of tax avoidance losses, as has been done on earlier occasions.

Secondly, he drew attention to quite a bit of Press and other comment from legal and accounting firms, including some correspondence in the national Press from major accounting firms, indicating in very clear terms the success that the Government's legislation has been having in stamping out tax avoidance. For these reasons I would suggest that the wording of the matter of public importance is inaccurate and unwarranted. I seek leave to table the list of legislation that has been enacted by the present Federal Treasurer since 1977.
Leave granted.

The second figure that appears on page 249 of that Budget statement comes equally out of the blue. In that respect I cannot do better than to quote this morning's Australian Financial Review editorial, which states:
No reliance can be based upon the estimates of recovery as a result of anti-tax avoidance measures or of higher penalties for delayed tax payments.

For this latter category, the Budget papers provide the extraordinary estimate that in the current financial year an extra $615m will be collected as a result of the increase in penalty interest . . . . even though this will not be retrospective but will apply only from the date of passage of the appropriate legislation through Parliament.

This figure is simply not credible without some evidence as to the details of amounts outstanding. I suggest it is very much incumbent upon later speakers in this debate, if they want to restore any shred of credibility to the Government' s case in respect of these sorts of figures that are being bandied about, that that kind of information be in fact produced. The reality of the matter is that when we read together the figures that appear in relation to the likely recoupment from anti-tax avoidance measures, we find a situation in which the Government is clearly trying to convey the appearance that those measures will generate some additional revenue return but at the same time they are trying to create an impression that there will not be all that much money to be gleaned from the operation of these measures because all the other measures which have been operating in the past have been so successful. The figures in themselves have no inherent credibility. They come across, they shriek across, to an observer, as the product of a manipulative exercise by a government anxious to make a political point but quite unable to make an accounting point or an arithmetical point that will withstand any kind of scrutiny whatsoever.

There is simply no reason to believe this Government when it claims to be operating effectively in the tax evasion-tax avoidance field. The evidence for that assertion that I now make is amply before us. It appears in the long record of failure to take quick remedial legislative action against various things that clearly demand and have demanded such remedial action. I will mention some of those delays in a few moments. It becomes evident in the extraordinary failure of the administrative side of the Government's tax collection operations as evidenced, for example, by the extraordinary delay that took place in chasing up those large numbers of people involved in the sales tax rort, particularly involving new cars. I raised this matter in the Parliament on 21 May 1980. On the information available to me it had obviously been known to the Government for a year or so before that. But the first raids which took place to bring this malpractice to a halt did not occur until a few months ago, in May 1982.

The best evidence of all of the Government's failure to respond effectively-its inaction, its timidity, its pathological lethargy in these matters, as I said yesterday in referring to this subject-is the Government's own statement out of the mouth of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 27 June in the context of the McCabe- Lafranchi report. My colleague Senator Walsh has taken us through some of the key elements in that saga. So too has Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle today, in reminding us, as I reminded her in Question Time today, that as early as January 1975 opinions were coming out of the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney- General's Department to the effect that criminal action could have been taken then against those people involved as promoters, vendors and certainly as purchasers of the companies in question in the bottom-of-the-harbour arrangements. It was not incumbent upon the then Labor Government to take that any further because when that opinion was received in 1975 it was immediately referred, as it should have been, to the police for the further gathering of evidence. The police did not report until November 1976, after we were out of office, saying: 'Yes, there is ample evidence to support that legal opinion. You can go ahead and prosecute'. All of this is in the Treasurer's statement.

What happened? The whole thing disappeared into that limbo land of lost causes which has been constituted by the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury over the last six or seven years and nothing further happened. It was all put into the 'too-hard' basket. The saga of inaction continued. No criminal actions were brought and, as a result, while the Government fiddled, while Mr Brian Maher and his criminal conspirator cohorts prospered and while the revenue burned, nothing was done. The problem has been more than one of simple inaction on the part of the Government; it has been a failure of the whole legislative strategy the Government has adopted towards taxation.

Let me spend the last few minutes available to me to speak on this matter explaining constructively, I hope, for Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in a demonstration that we are not simply scoring personal points in this matter but have a very serious policy point to make about the way in which the Government has been proceeding. I will explain very briefly what the Government's legislative strategy is, if it can be dignified with that description, and what by contrast ours is and why it is better.

I suppose there are four elements in the Government's anti-avoidance strategy. The first is piecemeal legislation, which is essentially designed of course to close the stable door after a particular horse has bolted. The Minister, in the document she tabled, gives us a list. If it is the same table as the one the Treasurer was wavering about a couple of months ago, as I suspect it is, it will no doubt retail the 50-odd legislative measures involving 700-odd pages of legislation of a piecemeal kind that this Government has been responsible for. That is the first element in the strategy. We have seen lots of bits of legislation of that kind, most of them coming along two, three, four or five years after the horse in question has bolted, but they have come along and there have been quite a lot of them.

The second element in the strategy is the purported general anti-avoidance provision, the famous Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which followed the notorious collapse of section 260 through the iniquitous interpretations of the Barwick High Court of Australia, commencing, not in 1978, as the Treasurer would have us believe in his statement of 27 June, but in fact commencing that chain of interpretation back in the early 1970s and only finally dragging the section to a grinding halt in 1977 in Cridland's case. The third element in the Government's strategy, apart from Part IVA, are the criminal penalties that are involved in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980 for crude evasion behaviour of the particular kind involved in bottom-of-the- harbour schemes and certain others of like kind. The final element in the Government's strategy- again if it can be so dignified with that description-is the use now of retrospective legislation, not as an all-purpose weapon for dealing with contrived, blatant, artifical schemes, but to be used in very exceptional cases such as the Government acknowledges exist, in its words, in the case again of bottom-of-the-harbour vendors.

There are obvious weaknesses in that four-part strategy. Let me say, as succinctly as I possibly can, what they are. In the case of piecemeal legislation, there is no doubt that particular remedial legislation to deal with trusts and partnerships and certain other problems which show up will go on being necessary. The Labor Party certainly accepts that and advocates that. Our proposed amendments to section 26A in relation, for example, to capital gains, is a demonstration of some of the kinds of piecemeal measures that are needed. But piecemeal legislation is no good at all to deal with blatant, contrived artificial schemes because one can only ever come in after the event. It is not a prospective solution that is needed when one is talking about blatant and contrived schemes; it is a retrospective solution. The kinds of measures that are writ large in the table that has been brought down by the Government today and incorporated in Hansard are simply not the kinds of measures that are calculated to deal effectively with blatant and contrived schemes. The solution for those, as we have said so many times in this chamber, is retrospective legislation, not just in odd and isolated cases when the Government steels its electoral nerve and takes the risk of doing so, but in all the cases which satisfy that description of blatant and contrived in the nature of the schemes involved. What is needed is: Firstly, piecemeal legislation; secondly, retrospective legislation on an across the board basis against those schemes which satisfy that description; and, thirdly-this is where we finally differ from the Government-a general anti-avoidance provision, not of the kind contained in Part IVA, which is a very draconian measure designed of its very character again to be effective against only blatant and contrived schemes and accordingly conferring very narrow discretions on the Commissioner of Taxation, but a proper re-write of section 260, the details of which we have spelled out on numerous occasions. I did it at length in this place on 11 June 1981 and I will not do it now in the 30 seconds available to me. But that combination of approaches is a rational legislative response and not an irrational one of the kind that the Government has produced.

SPEECH.PARA: As to special retrospective legislation that has been foreshadowed to recover moneys lost to revenue by bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, can any listener doubt that this complete and utter reversal of Liberal Party policy is in direct line with the policy that has been advocated in this chamber not for weeks, not for months, but for years by the ALP? SPEECH.PARA: The Senate itself might be said to have taken something of a lead in this matter. Until recent times when the pressure has become inexorable the Government has not done anything to bring about the demise of tax avoidance with consequent burdens on the ordinary taxpayers.

The ordinary Australian people are not conned. The spectacle of Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, last night handing out a few dollar notes as though they were how-to-vote cards is absolutely pathetic. Every recipient of his promises holds them up to the light to see whether they have that thread through the middle, the thread of authenticity. They do not trust the Prime Minister any more. Certainly this Government is not trusted by the general public to bring about a fairness and an evenhandedness in the tax reforms which are so necessary to lift the burden off the ordinary wage and salary earner. For the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to suggest that the Government has led public opinion in this regard is actually an utter reversal of the truth. The cries of anguish of ordinary Australians, the feeling of unfairness which pervades society, the articulation by the Labor Party of those complaints, eventually penetrated even the hallowed fields of Nareen and some action has been forthcoming.

The Budget that was brought down last night to my mind reinforces the view that the Government really believes that the income tax system cannot be made as equitable as it ought to be. The heavy impost by way of indirect taxation demonstrates to me that the Government feels that income tax is no longer a fair and evenhanded way in which to raise revenue. The move to increase tax savagely on cigarettes, petrol, beer, common items of every day use and enjoyment, and the introduction of new taxes on many items-this has not got out to the public yet but soft furnishings, curtains, blankets, sheets and other ordinary things for household use will be taxed indirectly-show that the Government has given up its hope to construct a fair income tax system.
