PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Repatriation ( Special Overseas Service) Act 1962.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This is a Bill to amend the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962

Recently the High Court of Australia handed down a decision in the case of Mrs Nancy Law v the Repatriation Commission. The decision was favourable to Mrs Law and reinforced the determinations and opinions that had been handed down in two previous Federal Court cases.

The broad details of the case were that the late Mr Law was a WWII veteran who had been a POW (J). He had developed a psychiatric condition as a result of his POW experiences. He smoked and died of lung cancer. The argument for his widow was that his psychiatric condition, in part at least, was causal to his smoking habit which in turn appears likely to have caused his terminal cancer. Therefore his death should be accepted as due to war service.

The details of the case are not the important issue as there are better examples of the adverse effects of war service on our veterans: for example, the disastrous effect of Agent Orange on Vietnam Veterans and their families.
The case of Mrs Nancy Law v the Repatriation Commission, however, gave hope to Vietnem Veterans.

Broadly, this case had spelt out to the determining authorities what criteria they must adopt in their decisions. The determinations had gone into great detail to define the entitlement provisions of the Repatriation Act. Once again the value of the ''arisen out of'' provision (101 (1) (B)) in the principal act (Repatriation Act 1920) was brought to public attention.

Although Vietnam Veterans do not have an equivalent provision in their Act, the Special Overseas Service Act, it has been thought that they are covered by an equivalent provision-the ''Occurrence'' provision in Section 6 (1) of the Special Overseas Service Act viz: ''Has resulted from an occurrence''.
Unfortunately this appears not to be the case.
The Repatriation Commission has already appealed against a determination in Mr Kenneth Jacobs' favour on the principal basis that:
''the Tribunal misapplied section 6 of the Act by treating the expression 'has resulted from' as if it were 'arising out of'.''
Other grounds for appeal are given but that is the substance of the case.
It is obvious then that the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 needs to be amended-and quickly.

There is a major anomaly between the eligibility for repatriation benefits for Vietnam veterans who are covered by the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 and the eligibility for repatriation benefits for WWII veterans who are covered by the Repatriation Act, 1920.
The anomaly arises out of the existence in the Repatriation Act 1920 of a section designated as 101(1)(B). This section is very short but it is of crucial importance. It reads:

''Upon the incapacity or death . . . of any member of the forces whose incapacity or death has arisen out of, or is attributable to his war service . . . the Commonwealth shall, subject to this Act, be liable etc . . . ''

This section allows for the acceptance of a disability which can be said to have ''arisen out of'' war service. It is under this section that a condition may be accepted that has developed as a consequence of an earlier accepted disability. For example, a serviceman may have a nervous condition accepted as being due to war service, and later develops a heart condition because of his '' nerves''. The heart condition can then in turn be accepted under Section 101(1)( B), as it can be said to have ''arisen out of'' war service. Although war service itself may not have directly caused the condition, it is a sequel to another accepted disability.

Senators will appreciate that as Vietnam veterans get older, a decreasing number of their claims will be based on direct service causation and an increasing number of claims will be based on a condition arising as a consequence of an earlier accepted condition.

Unfortunately the Vietnam veteran does not have this extremely valuable clause or an equivalent clause in his Act and so this highly relevant line or argument is denied him. He is thus surely discriminated against in in comparison with WWII veterans. It is a most inequitous situation.

For a Vietnam veteran the grounds of acceptance of a condition as being due to service lie in Sections 6(1)(4)(5) and (6) of the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. Broadly this is the equivalent of Sections 101(1)(A) and 101( 2) of the Repatriation Act 1920.

The grounds under these sections are far more restrictive, confining the acceptance of being on the basis of direct origin from an ''occurrence'' during his service. This, by and large, rules out acceptance of ''sequel'' conditions and diseases.

As I have said, this puts Vietnam veterans at a great disadvantage already in comparison to World War II veterans and as they get older and develop more ' sequel' type conditions this disadvantage will become increasingly marked.

It is important that Senators realise that Vietnam veterans' eligibility for Repatriation benefits lies in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act and not in the main body of the Act, which is called the Repatriation Act 1920.

The two Acts are quite distinct and there is a major anomaly between them. This anomaly, which greatly disadvantages the Vietnam veteran as distinct from his World War II predecessors, can be rectified simply with the amendment I have proposed today.
This amending Bill which the Australian Democrats have presented to the Senate simply inserts an additional sub-clause viz. 'has risen out of or is attributable to his special service'.
The former clause 6 (1) which read:

'Upon the incapacity or death of a member of the Forces whose incapacity or death has resulted from an occurrence that happened during a period of special service of the member (including the contracting of a disease during such a period), the Commonwealth is, subject to this Act, liable to pay to the member, to the dependants of the member or to both, as the case may be, pensions in accordance with Division 1 of Part III of the Repatriation Act as applied by the next succeeding section;is now amended by omitting this sub-section and substituting the following:

'(1) Upon the incapacity or death of a member of the Forces whose incapacity or death- (a) has resulted from an occurrence that happened during a period of special service of the member (including the contracting of a disease during such a period); or
(b) has risen out of or is attributable to his special service,

the Commonwealthis, subject to this Act, liable to pay to the member, to the dependants of the member or to both, as the case may be, pensions in accordance with Division 1 of Part III of the Repatriation Act as applied by section 7.'.

If I may now refer back to the Law v Repatriation Commission case, it is important to realise that the Law case has not opened up a legal 'loop hole' for veterans and their dependants to exploit. It means that the Repatriation and associated Acts are to be administered with the spirit and intent that always should have been the case but unfortunately were not.

I am sure that the spirit and intent of the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 was to put Vietnam veterans on an equal footing with World War II veterans. It has not turned out to be the case.
The appeal against Jacobs by the Repatriation Commission on the grounds I have outlined has shown this. It is important now that we legislate to put the spirit and intent into the Act.
My arguments to you are not based on legal technicalities but on the grounds of compassion and equality.

After all, Vietnam veterans served their country in a theatre of war-many of them against their will-just as did World War II veterans and I can see no rational reason why their grounds of entitlement should not be on an equal footing.
This amendment will give equality to Vietnam veterans.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening before the presentation of the Budget I was speaking on the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment ( Countervailing Duties) Bill, drawing attention to the closer economic relations with New Zealand which are designed to have a commencement date of 1 January 1983. I pointed out that this particular arrangement is being sold to the Australian people as an overall package which will be beneficial, not in each of its elements but as a package. One can appreciate the need for our two countries to move together in certain matters. One can also appreciate the benefits that will be derived from having a larger market-18 million people. However, I believe the relative advantages flow disproportionately to New Zealand. It effectively means that its market will be six times larger than previously.

SPEECH.PARA: I did point out yesterday that, of all the States, Tasmania has the potential to be damaged most. This is the matter that does concern me. I also expressed concern that the level of debate was much more sophisticated and much more advanced in New Zealand than it was here in Australia. This is also a matter that concerns me. I join with my colleagues Senator Peter Rae and Max Burr in calling for an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into this whole matter, not only to look at the economic aspects but to widen the general framework of usual IAC inquiries and to look also at the social implications, because of all the States, Tasmania has the potential to be most damaged. I refer to paper products, wood, timber and horticulture; I could go right through the whole list . About 80 percent of the items imported from New Zealand are also produced in Tasmania. I believe it would be a travesty of justice to allow such an important agreement to take place without some sort of inquiry. True, there is some level of public debate, and I have encouraged the setting up of panel discussions between producers in Australia and producers in New Zealand, but there is a flaw in this argument because no matter what sorts of agreements and understandings are reached between producers in the respective countries, unless we can tie up the merchants and marketeers they will drive carts through these arrangements.

There is a need for a comprehensive examination of this whole scheme. The New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement was very one-sided. Australian entry to New Zealand was restricted in so many ways. Import licensing has been a continual problem. So NAFTA had to come to an end; we had to have something better to take its place. We all appreciate that in respect of Third World markets Australia and New Zealand can work co-operatively rather than competitively against each other, which would force down the price. We see that in relation to meat products and we saw it last year in relation to onions in New Zealand. What does worry me, because of the market support schemes and the export incentives which are to be phased out over a very protracted time in New Zealand, is that New Zealand will be able to move in and capture Tasmania's mainland markets. These markets, once lost, will be very difficult to recover. We all know of the difficulties Tasmania, as an island State, experiences in regard to reliability of transport to the mainland and in keeping costs down. Our Government has done quite a lot to extend freight equalisation. In the event of a strike affecting goods that are normally carried by sea, freight equalisation will be available on a north and south-bound basis. But that does not overcome the problem that once those markets are lost they will be very difficult to recover.

The phasing-out period will be critical; it will be the time when these active marketeers from New Zealand will move in. Let us acknowledge it, they are far better than most of their counterparts in Australia, with the exception of those in the wool and wheat industries and probably the sugar industry. Let us look at the other industries; at the flow of imports of wood products, including wood pulp, and all the other things that are causing problems at the moment. Already we are reliably told that a major distributor in Australia has come to some sort of contractual arrangement for the supply of peas next year-we do not yet know the extent of it-with Waties-Pict in New Zealand. This is the thin edge of the wedge. Tasmania has the potential; its north-west coast makes it Australia's garden State. We could lose that advantage. I pointed out that the two potential growth areas in Tasmania are tourism and horticulture. Will we sacrifice these industries without even an inquiry?

We are talking about the customs tariff anti-dumping legislation. As far as most people in Australia are concerned this legislation is pretty hopeless. One has almost to be able to prove oneself bankrupt-it is too late then-before any recognition is made of the scheme. Are we going to wait for our industries- depressed as they are in Tasmania, which has the highest unemployment rate in the Commonwealth-to be further disadvantaged without any sort of major inquiry? It does concern me that the chief negotiator is about to retire next year, so we will put it in place and will not have to carry the can for some of the potential residual problems. Who is going to carry this can? The people of Tasmania. It will be the small industries that are affected. There has been agreement with some industries. I give a lot of credit to the dairy industry, which has worked very hard to come to some arrangement. Arrangements have been made with the wine and other industries. But there will be gaps because there are not always adequate panels and discussion has been left far too late. If the agreement has to come into effect on 1 January next year agreements will have to be signed well before that date.

We were told by the chief negotiator that we will introduce quick track anti- dumping provisions but, after inquiring what they were to be, we were told that some of the red tape would be cut by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch). What is the difference between these new arrangements and the previous ones that have proved so ineffective? It has really been quite a racket . The New Zealanders have brought certain textile goods from Asia, had buttons sewn on or some other minor alteration made and sent them to Australia under an incentive scheme.

What we need is some contractual arrangement during the phase-in period. New Zealanders may believe they need this advantage over a fairly extended period after 1985, but we need some limitation on imports from New Zealand to protect our industries. At the same time we need a high ranking inquiry. Despite all the reservations I have about the Industries Assistance Comm- ission-I feel it has prejudiced employment opportunities in Tasmania in the past-I think at this late stage it is the only body that can effectively conduct such an inquiry within the limited time frame. The alternative is to defer the commencement date so that there is adequate time for inquiry and examination. We all know the world economy is in difficulty. To embark upon this sort of thing would put industries at risk in economically vulnerable States. The Callaghan Inquiry into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania said that Tasmania is beautiful, Tasmania is tranquil but Tasmania is economically vulnerable. Are we going to disregard these opening remarks in the Callaghan report and suddenly open up the industries of our State to this sort of unfair competition? We ask for fairness.

What I am frightened of is that if comparative advantages are seen because of New Zealand export incentives and support schemes some of the processors could conveniently move their operations to New Zealand and ship into Melbourne and Sydney at the cost of the growers in Tasmania. Despite the panel discussions between the growers in Tasmania and New Zealand the processors could shift. These are the things that we have to be somewhat concerned about. There has to be some sort of agreement at least to minimise the imports from New Zealand, certainly during the phase-out period of these export incentives which are so beneficial to exporters. They are so beneficial that some New Zealand manufacturers will disregard the local market and send their goods into Australia because it pays more.

We have problems and we have to make sure that we put into place quick track anti-dumping provisions and not just use a term which is flamboyant, which is meaningful to most people, but does not have substance. We have to put some sort of substance into this type of arrangement; otherwise many people in Tasmania will be in trouble. Tasmanian producers are concerned about this. I wish this concern would filter through to a few more people who have the responsibility to try to put this closer economic relations package into place. So many people say : 'It will be all right. You don't have to worry. We will look after that sort of thing'. It is time we asked for a deeper examination of some of those platitudes and what lies behind them.

As I mentioned before, the track record of the New Zealanders exporting to Australia has not been good. What can this Parliament do about it? If major changes are not to be made to the anti-dumping provisions, changes will not come through this Parliament but will be a result of Executive direction. So despite what we might say in this place, if we cannot get an inquiry under way or any legislative action or agreement within either the House of Representatives or the Senate we will be presented with a fait accompli. There is danger to Tasmania and I believe Tasmanians should stand up for their State to make sure that there are adequate safeguards. At least let us have an inquiry so that we can ease our consciences. I believe it would be irresponsible if we Tasmanians representing one State did not put our State ahead of some future overall package. That offers more benefits to New Zealand. The New Zealand Government is staking its political life on this. It is talking about the big benefits that will flow to New Zealand. True enough, there will be benefits, but at whose expense? If they are to be at the expense of Tasmania I will not have a part of them. If we do not stand up now all the things we have said in the past will be just mere rhetoric. Time is running out and we have to take some sort of action. I draw this matter of concern to the attention of the Senate and I invite the participation of all Tasmanian senators at least. I applaud Senator Peter Rae, Max Burr and others who have expressed their concern.
Senate Tate-And Senator Tate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Tate has been quite active. I acknowledge that he brought the chief negotiator to Tasmania. This is the sort of action that we need. We need a more informed public so that this thing is not pushed on to us to the detriment of the producers and the people of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment ( Countervailing Duties) Bill gives Australia power to retaliate against our major trading partners in the event that they use unfair and unscrupulous tactics against exports from Australia to their countries. To the degree that this Bill gives us some additional power in this area in a very restrictive field, the Australian Democrats support it. We support the fact that Australia is prepared to stand on its dignity and to negotiate in a bilateral way with its major trading partners. The Australian Labor Party has said that this Bill embraces the much wider issue of our general trading policy. I agree that it does. I believe it is now urgent for our country to have a fundamental look at how we are conducting our trading negotiations with our trading partners. The Labor Party has said that the Government should devise a more consistent and responsible trade policy in line with the principles of the multilateral trade negotiations and the ideals of the Kennedy and Tokyo rounds of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. I want to query that cosy little suggestion. Is it in Australia's interest to talk about trading relationships on the basis of multilateral principles or should we be more concerned with a bilateral approach ? Should Australia not look at its trading association on a country to country basis?

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill arose because we were concerned that the export of Australian lamb to the United States of America was being discriminated against. The Australian Government objected. The matter was settled amicably, but only because we threatened to introduce countervailing duties in Australia. In other words, when we stood up for our rights something was done. A stronger approach to bilateral trade means that we can talk about a quid pro quo. When Australia is a party to a multilateral trade negotiation, it is far too easy for its voice to be swamped by the attitudes and points of view put forward by much larger and more powerful trading countries. Australia has a very important trading relationship with Japan. Why can we not say to the Japanese. 'If we are to allow more Japanese cars into this country, why will you not allow more of our beef, for example, to be exported to Japan?' There should be some give and take on a country-to- country basis.

We tend to look on our trading arrangements as a matter of principle. We are all too ready to squander our hard-earned foreign currency on the altar of some principle which we may call one day free trade, or some other such principle. In the hard cold world of trade, most countries do not talk about principles; they look on trade negotiations as a matter of hard business negotiation, and we should do the same. Many years ago I happened to be sitting in the Visitors' Gallery of the House of Commons. I was amazed to sit there for a whole afternoon while important British parliamentarians debated whether they should drop the tariff or excise on Spanish sherry by a few pence per gallon. That would not seem to us in Australia, I am sure, to be a very important matter. It occupied the British Parliament for a whole afternoon. Its members wanted to know, if the tariff on Spanish sherry was dropped by a penny and that represented to Spain an additional market of X million British pounds, what Britain, as a trading nation , would get in return. It was the principle of a quid pro quo, and it concerned the British Parliament. I suggest that this approach with our major trading partners should concern the Australian Parliament.

This matter has arisen in the case of exports of our primary products to the United States. I ask the question: What about unfair practices that are all too frequently applied against our exports of manufactured goods to countries such as the United States? I cite an example. A very large Australian manufacturer negotiated an important contract to supply to the United States turbine blades for aeroplane engines. It negotiated it fairly. Its quality was thoroughly investigated. Its price was satisfactory. The contract was drawn up. The ink on the pen was wet. The contract was about to be signed. Suddenly the American Government said, 'Halt'. Some lobbyist had said, 'We can make these blades in the United States. Why should we be buying them from Australia?' The 'Buy American' Act was imposed against Australia and that contract was never consumated. These sorts of things apply in most trading countries. The Japanese have all kinds of non-tariff mechanisms to limit, to stop or at least to control the flow of imports into their country. They have these mechanisms for a very good reason. They are concerned about hard earned foreign currency.

Australia's trading account is in a critical situation. Our balance of paymens blew out this year by $8 billion. That means that we spent on imports $8 billion more than we earned from our exports. This deficit was covered by the inflow of foreign capital. One wonders how long we can continue to attract this inflow of foreign capital. Certainly it means that to keep trading in this way we must maintain very high rates of interest in Australia, at least comparable with those in the United States. This Bill raises the basic question of how Australia should trade-whether we are going about our trading negotiations in a businesslike way, whether we are prepared to negotiate as other countries negotiate, taking into account the cold hard facts of life, or whether we are too ready to drop tariffs and to spend our foreign exchange without getting anything in return.

The question and answer read as follows-
Senator Sir John Carrick: On 16 February 1982, Senator Rae asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question, without notice:

What research work has been undertaken to assess which industries and which areas in Australia will be most adversely affected if the closer economic relations with New Zealand proposals go ahead? If such work has been undertaken, what are the results and will they be made available? If the work has not been undertaken, will the Minister put to his colleague a suggestion that the work should be undertaken before any further discussions take place with New Zealand?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In accordance with guidelines contained in the Joint Comminuque issued by the Australian and New Zealand Prime Ministers in Wellington in March 1980, officials on both sides have undertaken a series of studies on methods and detailed arrangements by which the two governments might proceed to implement progressive moves towards a closer trans-Tasman economic relationship (CER).

A report by official, was presented to the two governments early in 1981. The report contained the basis of possible new trading arrangements, including those for the gradual and progressive elimination of tariffs and quantitative restrictions and measures to ensure fair competition in trans-Tasman trade. The report indicated that officials had established a broad area of common ground. However, as confirmed by the Minister for Trade and Resources in discussions with Prime Minister Muldoon and other New Zealand Ministers in May 1981, differences of view remained in respect of a number of issues which are seen as fundamental to any new agreement. These include the setting of a firm date for the ultimate elimination of quantitative restrictions between the two countries, the future of performance-based export incentives in trans-Tasman trade, the position of dairy products under a CER, and sensitive horticulture issues.

Officials have continued to study these and other outstanding questions, and as appropriate consultations have taken place between Australian and New Zealand industry groups including the two dairy industries. Senior officials meetings are to be held in April, as preparation for early Ministerial level negotiations aimed at reaching agreement on a CER package which could then be submitted to the two governments for final decision.

Several of the issues identified for study by the Prime Ministers reflected recognition of the fact that further liberalisation of trans-Tasman trade could have unfair adverse impact on certain industries in each country given differences in the nature and extent of agricultural support/ stabilisation arrangements, export incentive schemes and tariffs applied against third countries. It was also necessary to take account of such factors in devising possible new trading arrangements.

Any assessment of the potential impact of a CER on Australian industries needs to have regard to features of the trading framework that has evolved under NAFTA . Under existing arrangements, imports from New Zealand enter Australia either free or at very low rates of duty. New Zealand exporters also have the benefit of generous performance-based export incentive arrangements. On the other hand, many Australian exports to New Zealand face duties which are generally higher and are further restricted by import licensing. Under an appropriately structured CER, these and other factors contributing to inequality of trading opportunity and unfair competition would be gradually removed. The proposed new arrangements would have, as their primary purpose, the elimination of imbalances in opportunity confronting Australian producers in trans-Tasman trade.

It is not expected that any Australian industries would be adversely affected at the outset of a CER. However, over time it could be expected that some rationalisation and restructuring of industry would occur with the removal of trade barriers leading to increased trade and competition between the two countries. However the gradualism inherent in CER mechanisms should ensure that any adjustment pressures in either country can be accommodated. Overall, such pressures are unlikely to be of major significance when compared with those occurring within the domestic economy and as a result of Australia's trade with the rest of the world.

It should be noted that consultations with State Governments and interested industry organisations have been held at key stages in the CER exercise. The Government is committed to making public the proposed new arrangements and consulting fully with interested parties before final decisions are taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee recessed for dinner I had just referred to a statement put out on 15 June 1982 by Mr John Kerin, the shadow Minister for Primary Industry in which he indicated that he had, on that day, written to the Minister for Primary Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) and the Minister for Primary Industry 'advising them of the Australian Labor Party's guarantee on the fertiliser legislation for the next three years to June 1985.' SPEECH.PARA: . . . farmers would receive the superphosphate and nitrogenous fertiliser subsidies after July 1, 1982, providing the legislation, currently deferred in the Senate by the actions of the Labor Party and the Democrats, is passed in its existing form.
So a very clear statement was made on 22 June. A little later in the Press release, the following appears:

Mr McVeigh said ensuring that the subsidies could be paid to farmers in the period between July 1, 1982 and at the time the legislation is passed, would involve the co-operation of manufacturers, who would have records of sales made.

I think the public record is fairly clear-that the Government indicated that it was proposing to proceed with the legislation in its present form and saw the bounty or subsidy being paid retrospectively to 1 July.

I noted that, in his speech on the amendment, Senator Walsh conceded that there could be a short term advantage for farmers-that was his expression-in passing the Bill in its present form. I do not wish to canvass the matters that we canvassed at some length in the second reading debate, when I pointed out-I think it has been largely accepted in this debate, unlike the previous debate- that this is a measure which is meant to provide assistance for farmers. The other very important collateral issues which have been raised by honourable senators of the Opposition and of the Australian Democrats are not central to this legislation and really need to be dealt with in another context. Senator Collard, who spoke in support of the Bill, emphasised that this is a measure that aims to reduce costs to farmers.

Senator Macklin indicated that the Australian Democrats would accept the legislation on the premise that the Government would be happy to drop the legislation if it were blocked here. I can only put on the public record that the Government's wish is to see this legislation in place and operating as soon as possible. Senator Harradine asked in the course of the Committee debate for answers to some questions which he had raised previously. I must say that I had a little difficulty upon referring back to the Hansard in following some of the questions which were asked by him, as recorded, at page 2520 of 27 May 1982. I must say that there appeared to be some misapprehension about certain facts in those questions. He asked:

What will happen to the workers of Christmas Island? Has the Government given consideration to its guarantee to the manufacturer on Christmas Island which in turn has given a guarantee to Australian National Line that it will subsidise the shortfall in the carrying of phosphate from Christmas Island?

I am very puzzled about that because the existence of any such guarantee is not known to me or to my advisers and, of course, there is no manufacturer of superphosphate on Christmas Island. Certain people have contracts and, in turn, an arrangement or contract with the Australian National Line with respect to the carriage of phosphate from Christmas Island. But that is not a matter in which the Government is directly involved. Senator Harradine's next comment was:
When the ANL took over the ships of the British Phosphate Commission, a guarantee was given by the manufacturer, backed up by the Australian Government.

Again, that backing of the Australian Government is not a matter that is known to me or to my advisers. The fact is that they are commercial matters which have to be dealt with by the commercial parties and will not be resolved by the passage or non-passage of this legislation. I think that underlying much of Senator Harradine's concern in this matter, is, of course, the position of local manufacturers. In wishing to pursue the legislation in its present form the Government should not be understood to say that it is not concerned about the position of local suppliers. It will, in fact, keep the position of local suppliers under review and will, if necessary, consider action to assist the industry. In the meantime, of course, the industry has access to the normal anti -dumping measures, which have been the subject of some comment in the Senate earlier today. So the difference between the position of Senator Harradine and that of the Government on this matter is not one which involves the Government saying: 'This is not a matter which ought to be of government concern or interest'. Rather we say that, if one is concerned about the industry, the proper course is not to amend this legislation but rather to look to the normal processes used to protect industry in Australia.

Senator Harradine made to the Committee a number of comments which expressed his concern about the possible long term position of farmers, given that there might be a reduction in the capacity of Australian manufacturers to manufacture phosphate for Australian use. That reflected the sort of concerns which I think underlaid Senator Walsh's comments when, in leading for the Opposition, he spoke of the long term interests of farmers, as against possible short term benefits. It occurred to me, as I was listening to Senator Harradine, that really one could use the same argument to justify almost any amount of protection for any sector of Australian industry. The fact is that a trading country such as Australia is a substantial exporter and a substantial importer of a great variety and range of goods and products. I do not believe that the sort of analysis which was made by Senator Harradine can really become a basis for action in this case or, indeed, in others because I think one could apply his words equally to almost any area of activity in Australia and reach the conclusion that in all cases action should be taken to preserve whatever happens to be the status quo. The rural industry, having to live as it does in international markets, understanding their deficiencies and fluctuations, is able to make the judgments that, I believe, it has made, namely, that it wants access to international sources of fertilisers as well as to Australian sources- understanding that there are pluses and minuses in that proposition taken over a range of years.

As far as the other concern which was expressed by Senator Harradine about what authority the Minister might have under section 7 to withdraw a subsidy insofar as it might affect some overseas producer who might not be passing the subsidy on, I think that if one looks at the amending legislation it appears that that precise point is adequately covered. I refer to proposed new section 7 of the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill, which replaces existing section 7 and states:

Where the Minister is not satisfied that the prices being charged by the producer or importer to purchasers in respect of the sale of goods, being goods in respect of which subsidy is payable, are such as to pass on to the purchasers the full benefit of that subsidy, the Minister may direct that subsidy shall not be paid to that producer or importer.

So that, in the case of material that is imported as against material which is manufactured in Australia, the ministerial power extends to the passing on of the subsidy by the importer rather than the direct manufacturer, who might be out of the jurisdiction. It seems to me that that is quite an appropriate provision which provides a safeguard to both the revenue and to the farmer, about which Senator Harradine was concerned. I ask the Senate to support this legislation in its original form. It is, as a number of honourable senators have pointed out in the debate, a measure which is meant to provide some assistance to the rural community which, like so many sections of Australian industry, has been faced by difficulties of rising costs. This is one of the very few areas in which assistance of this nature is given to the rural industry and I commend the legislation to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important piece of legislation. It is also complex and difficult. It concerns the Australian Public Service, which is a most important organisation. But appeals and the structure of the Commonwealth Public Service are probably not of great interest to the community at large; so before I commence my remarks perhaps I may say that anyone listening to the broadcast should probably switch off now, unless he is particularly interested in the structure and appeals procedures of the Commonwealth Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is a combination of the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill 1981 and substantial and important amendments moved to that Bill by the present Government in the House of Representatives. The Bill in turn amends the Public Service Act 1922 and numerous other Acts. As I have said, the legislation is complex and far reaching. It should have called for substantial and detailed consultation with the Public Service organisations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, being those organisations directly affected by the proposed changes to the legislation. Whilst it is true that in respect of many of the changes that are proposed by the Bill there has been a good deal of consultation and, indeed, agreement between the Government and the appropriate unions on necessary changes which might be made, in respect of several very important and contentious matters the degree of consultation between the Government and the unions has been at best perfunctory and at worst non-existent.

Some of the important matters contained in the Bill saw the light of day only a few weeks ago, before the Bill was debated in the House of Representatives, when the Government circulated its amendments to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill 1981. On other matters there has been a history of consultation and discussion going back in some instances to 1973. There has been consultation via the Joint Council and by other means. I make these preliminary comments to indicate the context in which this legislation has been introduced. It is fair to say that the Government has been somewhat slipshod in its handling of this legislation, as indeed it is in respect of most other matters. Perhaps if the Government had had the sense to embark on a thorough-going process of consultation with the unions involved, there may have been a greater measure of agreement on proposed changes to the Public Service legislation. At the very best, a great deal of the confustion and haste surrounding the introduction of the present Bill could have been avoided.

It is important to indicate the extent of interest in and the magnitude of the promotion appeals system in the Australian Public Service. I understand that in 1980 approximately 20,000 appeals were lodged, involving some 70,000 appellants, of whom at least 55,000 were not engaged in merely technical protective appeals, trying to protect their then existing status. If this circumstance is correct, it seems plain that legislation affecting the promotion appeals system should not be introduced without very thorough consultation and an earnest attempt to seek agreement on the matters proposed.

Having said that, I wish to make it clear that the Opposition supports many of the proposed measures in the Bill. Many of the reforms have had a long history, and we think that they are eminently sensible reforms. Those have our firm support. But unfortunately the same cannot be said for some other parts of the Bill. This Bill has two main objects-firstly, to abolish the divisional structure of the Australian Public Service; secondly, to make changes to the promotion, selection and appeal processes within the Public Service. The Opposition supports the proposal to abolish the divisional structure of the Australian Public Service. Although to many this proposal sounds radical, it is soundly based and there is broad support for it. Indeed, there is a history of support for the proposal.

The Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, the so-called Coombs Commission, reported in 1976. That Commission considered that the present divisional structure was outmoded and of doubtful utility. The hierarchical nature of the Service at present is composed in the following way. Firstly, the First Division of the Public Service consists of permanent heads of departments and on occasions other very senior positions as determined by the Governor- General. Secondly, the Second Division of the Public Service consists of senior executives of the Service, deputy secretaries, first assistant secretaries, and some others. Thirdly, the Third Division consists of clerical and professional positions, entry to which is controlled by examination or by special qualification in some instances. Finally, the Fourth Division comprises the rest of the staff of the Australian Public Service, and most of the Government's work force is in the Fourth Division. In fact, more than 70 per cent of the Public Service staff are engaged in that Division. The Coombs Royal Commission, to which I have referred, criticised the divisional structure, pointing out that it is a source of caste and status and prohibits mobility in the Public Service. The Coombs Royal Commission report had this to say:
Criticisms of the divisional structure include the following:
(a) It has inhibited an objective assessment of the working requirements of lower Third Division positions;
(b) it precludes the promotion to Third Division positions of officers of the Fourth Division of proven capacity.
The Royal Commission went on to say:

The validity of these criticisms is accepted by most departments and staff associations and by the Public Service Board which proposes the abolition of the divisions and their replacement by a series of occupational groups.

The Commission went on to recommend that provisions for divisions be removed from the Public Service Act. This recommendation had the support of the Public Service organisations involved and naturally the support of the Public Service Board. So there is common ground between all major parties that this proposal of the Coombs Royal Commission be implemented.

Whilst supporting the proposal to abolish divisional groups, it is necessary to say that the full details of the restructuring and identifying of the occupational groups called for by the abolition of the divisions have not yet been made public. I think it is fair to say that the abolition of divisions is not in itself a means of effecting the removal of undesirable barriers to mobility within the Service. The Coombs Royal Commission acknowledged this but considered that its recommendations on entry and selection would assist in eradicating barriers to that mobility. The Opposition has taken up some parts of the Commission's report on this aspect and will be moving as an amendment proposed new section 33AA to ensure that barriers to mobility are as few as possible as a result of the abolition of these divisions.

The other major area of the Bill concerns itself with the proposed changes to the promotion, selection and appeals procedures. Many of the proposed changes are eminently sensible and non-contentious and, in fact, are the result of consultative processes with the Joint Council. However, others are not, and in fact the Government has refused discussion in some areas. In October 1981 a specific request was made by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that certain portions of the Bill be put aside to allow further consultation and discussion. That request was not acceded to by the Fraser Government. In saying that, it is not a question of saying that the Government has to follow the dictates or requests of the ACTU in relation to these matters; but it is foolhardy, in this area of industrial relations, not to allow proper opportunities for affected parties to talk about proposed changes. Every treatise on industrial relations and every commentator on industrial relations make the point about the importance of consultation and discussion before reforms of this kind are implemented. Perhaps this Government's failure in this area is indicative of its handling of the whole area of industrial relations in Australia.

I wish to mention briefly some general areas of concern with the Bill. Clause 21 of the Bill repeals section 33 of the principal Act, which makes provision for the appointment of officers to the Second, Third, and Fourth divisions of the Service. This section is to be replaced by proposed new sections 33, 33A, 33B and 33C which make general provisions for the appointment of officers. Proposed new section 33A sets out the matters which the Public Service Board will determine in relation to the recruitment of staff. This provision is consistent in general with the recommendations of the Royal Commission for the details of the recruitment procedures to be delegated from the Board to departments, with the Board retaining a sort of monitoring role. However, this Bill fails to take up an important set of recommendations which are designed to declare in the statute itself a commitment to merit as a determinant to recruitment, selection and promotion. I would have thought that the Government would have been concerned to commit itself to merit as a determinant and a criterion of recruitment, selection and promotion. The Coombs Royal Commission stated:

It seems desirable to the Commission that the commitment to merit in recruitment and promotion should be declared by statute in a form which does not depend on particular techniques of measurement and leave scope for the Public Service Board to adopt its procedures in the light of growing knowledge and experience.

In the view of the Opposition, the full scheme proposed by the Royal Commission for enforcing merit selection as an ingredient of the development of a representative bureaucracy should be adopted. I repeat: One would have thought that would have been the view of this Government. I indicate that at the Committee stage we will be moving an amendment which will be directed towards emphasising the question of merit as the sole determinant in recruiting and promotion. We wonder why the Government has not also grasped that nettle because it is a very important and qualitative change which can be made to the whole structure and morale of the Australian Public Service. It is important to emphasise that merit and nothing but merit should be the determinant in creating a strong and efficient Public Service. The Royal Commission recognised this. It is clearly of importance that measures be taken to enshrine that principle in legislation. We regard that as a matter of the utmost importance and one which goes to the heart of improving the efficiency and creativity of the Australian Public Service.

Clause 28 of the Bill seeks to repeal the existing provisions in the legislation and proposes new legislation in regard to promotions and appeals. Under the old section 50 (8A) of the Act a promotions appeal committee was required to make full inquiries into the claims of the parties. That language has been subject to judicial interpretation. However, the proposed new section 50D (1) departs from the original language and proposes a substitute duty in the following form:
. . . the Committee shall inquire into the claims of each party to the appeal proceedings.

The reason for this change is not disclosed, either in the second reading speech or in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the Bill. I hope that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) will see that the reasons for that change are disclosed in the course of the debate which will follow, either tomorrow or on another day on which the Senate is sitting. The effect of the change will be to create needlessly a basis for judicial distinction to recent court decisions based on the existing wording of the Act. This is an important and fundamental change. The fundamental requirement of how a tribunal should go about its duty to inquire is now proposed to be changed without any obvious explanation being given by the Government. In our view, this is not a satisfactory situation at all. It should be remedied, and we propose to do so in the Committee stage of this debate.

Proposed new section 50D(2) also merits some attention. It proposes a highly detailed code of procedures to be followed when a promotions appeal committee conducts its inquiries. It is worth asking why these procedures have been detailed in this matter when the question has recently been the subject of judicial interpretation. I refer to the judgment of Ellicott, J., a former Attorney-General, in the case of Finch v. Goldstein, a matter heard by the Federal Court last year and known as Finch's case. In Finch's case, Mr Justice Ellicott held that the Promotions Appeal Committee had two basic duties. These were the duties he emphasised: First, the duty to be fair, and, secondly, the duty to make full inquiries. The learned judge went on to say that the Promotions Appeal Committee should afford, first of all, the right of each party to know the case put against him or her. I would have thought that an impeccable principle of British judicial precedent. Secondly, he said, that the Promotions Appeal Committee should afford the right of each party to put his or her case- again, I would have thought, a fundamental principle which should have been enshrined in this legislation.

However, Ellicott, J., did not hold that committees were obliged to conduct formal hearings or to allow legal representation. They were not obliged to do that. He considered that the regulations allowed the committee to prescribe the procedures to be used, subject to the duties, the overriding duties, which he had outlined in the course of his judgment in Finch's case. Regulation 109F made under the existing provisions instructs the appeal committee to 'make its inquiries without regard to legal form or solemnity'. Mr Justice Ellicott went on to conclude that in the circumstances of the case before him, the Promotions Appeal Committee had failed in its duty to act fairly.

The procedures in proposed new section 50D(2) have clearly been introduced as a reaction to the decision in Finch's case. But whether they reflect the more open and flexible approach recommended by Mr Justice Ellicott is, in our view, a matter of some debate. This Bill appears to place defined limits on the flexibility of response to particular cases which Mr Justice Ellicott was at such pains to preserve as a discretion of particular appeals committees. It just might be that a setting out of procedures to be followed by committees could assist in achieving a greater degree of fairness in hearings, but such a setting out should be the result of consultation with those concerned and should at all times preserve the approach which Mr Justice Ellicott recommended. Proposed new section 50D(2) exhibits none of these features and, if I may say so, we rely very much on the principles enunciated by Mr Justice Ellicott. Perhaps when he was in this place he never heard such commendation from Opposition spokesmen as he is getting tonight. In fact, it would seem that the flexibility of response advocated by Mr Justice Ellicott's decision has been cut down by the Government in this legislation. In this regard, attention should be drawn to the Minister's second reading speech in which he stated:

Recent court decisions appear to indicate that, as the Public Service Act is presently worded, the promotions appeal system should be conducted within an adversary framework and require a greater degree of legal formality than has in practice applied or is necessary or desirable to see that an appellant's case is fairly and fully heard and determined.

This statement of the Minister is a misreading of Mr Justice Ellicott's judgment . In fact, Mr Justice Ellicott held that the adversary or inquisitorial system, as it is sometimes called, or the distinction between the adversary or inquisitorial method, was not a useful way of analysing the function of committees; that what was needed was not necessarily a greater degree of legal formality but a higher standard of fairness in proceedings than had hitherto been applied.

I think we should be very wary of attempts to cut down the obligations which the general principles of administrative law place upon bodies such as the Public Service Board and other tribunals dealing with employee rights and duties . Since the decision in the Finch case, it is clear that the general principles of administrative law do apply to promotions appeal committees. There is always a danger that the detailed setting out of procedures may enable committees to ' read down' the obligations imposed on them by administrative law principles. In the content of this Bill that danger is apparent. I understand that parties to promotions appeal committee hearings report that the relatively greater openness and attention to fair practice now being observed by committees since the 1981 court decision is working well and is well received within the Public Service. It is difficult, therefore, to see why the Public Service Board has reacted in the way it has to the decision in Finch's case. Because of these views, the Opposition will move, in the Committee stage of this Bill, to preserve the flexibility recommended by His Honour Mr Justice Ellicott.

I want to deal with the other main contentious area of this Bill as I move a conclusion. I refer to proposed new sub-division F which deals with the furnishing of reports in cases of transfers, promotions and appeals. In part, these proposals deal with the issue which was involved in the disallowance by the Senate, on 23 March this year, of Statutory Rule No. 274 of 1981, made under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. I think it is necessary to understand that section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act creates a duty to provide reasons for certain administrative decisions. Schedule 2 to the Act had exempted from this requirement, for a period of 12 months or such longer period as was prescribed, decisions relating to promotions, transfers or appeals of individual members of the Australian Public Service. The initial 12 months' exemption of promotions appeal bodies in the Public Service had the support of the unions involved, as it was considered that it was an appropriate move in order to allow the Public Service Board time to develop measures to conform with the obligations imposed by the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The attempt by the Government to extend this period of exemption in March this year was quite unjustified and it was of little wonder that the Senate disallowed it. The Government has thus introduced this new sub- division F as its attempt to conform to the obligations imposed by section 13 of the Act to which I have referred.

The Opposition is concerned with the effect of proposed new sub-division F. In our view, it does not provide a similar level of protection as is afforded by section 13 of the Act. The reasons that must be provided under proposed new sub- division F are significantly different from those under section 13 and, in fact, the new proposals cut down substantially the rights afforded under the latter section. This was argued in meetings with the Public Service Board by the Australian Council of Trade Unions but the arguments were not accepted. We think the arguments should have been accepted. In our view there is no justification for treating one class of administrative decisions-those concerned with Public Service matters-differently from any other class of administrative decisions. Persons seeking reasons for a decision under the Public Service legislation should have the same rights as other persons can obtain under section 13 of the Act. We do not oppose the idea of a public service setting out in detail the rights of parties to obtain reasons for a decision, but any such provisions should reflect the principles embodied in section 13 of the Act. There are some provisions of this very important Bill to which the Opposition takes exception, but these will be dealt with and taken up in discussion at the Committee stage of the Bill.

Finally, let me say that although this is a technical Bill and perhaps not of much interest to the community in general, it is an important Bill which is regarded as important in terms of the morale, efficiency and imagination, as it were, or the capacity for constructive imagination and development of the Australian Public Service. There is much to commend in the Bill. Many of the matters in it will improve the efficiency of the Australian Public Service. But it is unfortunate, in our view, that on some major points the Government has acted with characteristic clumsiness and insensitivity to the rights of those involved. having said that, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been debating the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill 1982 and I am grateful to Senator Button for his comments. This is a very complex piece of legislation. The amending Bill consists of some 81 pages and it amends an Act of some 200 pages.
—If you call it complex you are still erring on the side of conservatism.

—That is right. I propose at the end of my remarks to invite the Senate to adjourn the debate and to postpone the Committee stage for particular reasons which I shall set out. I believe that the Government will be putting forward a series of amendments that have emerged from discussions since the Bill first saw the light of day. I think it only fair that honourable senators should know that before they discuss it during the Committee stage. We are interested in the comments made by the Opposition. We welcome any suggestions and, indeed, any revelation of proposed amendments prior to the actual Committee stage because I believe it could do only good if both sides of the chamber knew what was proposed.
—They have been circulated?

—That is of tremendous importance, and if there are others to be circulated or any questions, we would be very grateful to have them . Basically, as Senator Button said, this Bill emerges primarily from the 1976 Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. It is also sensitive to the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. It is a Bill which looks towards the structure, the promotion process and the promotion appeals process of the Commonwealth Public Service. I do not propose to speak in any detail on this tonight. I believe that the main points of contention will emerge in the Committee stage. Senator Button has acknowledged, as has been acknowledged in another place, that much of this legislation is highly acceptable to both the Opposition and the Government, and I thank him for that. It is inevitable that there will be points of contention.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Service in Australia plays a most significant part in the community and in society. It is essential, as an objective, skilled and expert body in the development of government. It is the wish of government that the conditions of the Public Service should be the optimum that the community can provide. It is the wish of government that matters relating to the structure, to promotion and to appeal should be eminently fair and practicable; that is, divorced as far as they can be from time wasting legalisms, at the same time, exposing the vital information to particular individuals while preserving the rights of all in that regard. Therefore, in the debate on individual matters of the Bill essential principles will be raised.

Senator Button raised the question of the Finch case and Mr Justice Ellicott. It will be a matter for the Senate to see where the equity should lie in a matter of both the nature and the conduct of appeals, whether the adversary system is good or bad, how much particular kinds of information should be exposed-all these kinds of things which I think get to the very heart of matters . I think all of us believe that the repeal of the provisions which established the Third Division and Fourth Division of the Public Service would be good. All of us, I am sure, believe that the provision to abolish seniority and to say that efficiency and merit shall be the bench marks is good. All of us want to ensure that the promotions and appeals systems are the best we can devise.

In that sense I will endeavour to have circulated to honourable senators the proposed amendments of the Government. The Government will welcome the availability of any proposed amendments by honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, by the Australian Democrats and by Senator Harradine. Since in these complex matters there is always a variety of questions, I wonder whether we could have forewarning if specific detail is needed so that I can ask the Public Service Board to have not only its technical officers but also the best of all possible advice in that regard available. I think that would be the civilised and effective way to conduct this debate. If any honourable senator of any party would like specific information on the Bill, the Public Service Act and the proposed amendments, the officers of the Public Service Board have informed me that they would be very willing to make themselves available for that type of discussion. I wonder whether, before we come to the Committee stage , that can be done. I thank Senator Button for his contribution. I commend the Bill, at its second reading, to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AIR ACCIDENTS (COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982CIVIL AVIATION (CARRIERS' LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 August 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I suggest to the Committee that we take the Bills separately and that we deal first with the Civil Aviation ( Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1982. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party has circulated to all honourable senators a proposal to delete clause 4 and to insert a whole number of new clauses at pages, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 of the Bill. In the first instance I want to refer to the debate that took place at the second reading stage and remind honourable senators that part of their obligations and responsibilities is to act on behalf of the public. We believe there is a public interest consideration here. With the threat of an early election I appreciate that we are placed in a somewhat difficult position in that the proposals for which we seek the support of the Committee would have the effect of altering the amount of compensation in respect of persons injured or killed in aircraft accidents. Whilst we will certainly be arguing that our proposals ought to be agreed to, it has been intimated to us that it would be difficult to defeat the Government's legislation and send it back to the House of Representatives for further consideration. Nevertheless, there is a case for suggesting to the Government that it ought to accept the amendments that we will place before the Committee for consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Committee that we are seeking to have the limitation and compensation raised from the proposed $100,000 to $130,000. For a long time-in fact, since 1976-the present Government has failed to take into account the rate of inflation when determining the level of compensation despite calls by both the Australian Labor Party and even Government members that there was a need to increase the amount of $45,000 payable in the event of death arising out of an aircraft accident. We do not believe that the public interest is being protected by arbitrarily fixing a figure of $100,000. Since this matter was first dealt with by the Parliament in 1959 there has always been a relationship between the amount of compensation and average weekly earnings. That criterion has been departed from in this case.

Of course, we reject the concept that a passenger has the right to take out special or additional insurance to protect himself if he feels that inadequate compensation is likely to be paid in the case of injury or death. We do not believe that such a situation serves the best interests of the travelling public . Many cases in the civil courts involve passengers or the families of passengers injured or killed in aircraft accidents who have been disadvantaged by inadequate compensation. We are of the view that it would be in the best interests of the travelling public if the airline operators accepted the higher level of compensation that we suggest should be paid. They should do this rather than concern themselves with the frills and in-flight services that have been part of airline competition. We are more concerned with the lives of passengers. We want to ensure that in the event of injury or death adequate compensation is paid to them or their families.

As was said in the second reading debate, we have a very high standard of aircraft safety in this country, particularly in the major airlines. The Department of Aviation's very high standards have resulted in a very low overall accident rate. I think it should be drawn to the attention of the Committee that over the last year there has been a rather heavy increase in the number of accidents involving privately owned aircraft and small charter aircraft. The Australian Labor Party is concerned about this because people, for work or leisure reasons, often quite unexpectedly travel by this type of transport. In many cases they are not aware of or do not think about compensation entitlements . After all, when one travels by air one does not think of the unexpected or the unthinkable. It is only when the unexpected happens and tragedy occurs that the question of compensation comes to the fore.

There are adequate reasons why the Committee and the Government should be prepared to take on board what the Opposition has had to say on these matters. We have taken into consideration not only the public interest but also the Government's own estimations in years gone by of the yardstick by which limited liability insurance should be gauged. Our very long-winded and extensive amendments are based on what we see as the responsibility of the Labor Party and also the Committee. In proposing $130,000 in the event of death we seek to relate compensation to average weekly earnings. We do not believe that increasing the level of compensation would represent a great amount of money to carriers but it would certainly represent a great amount of money to the persons affected by any accident arising from their travel on aircraft. The amendment which has been circulated in my name and which, as I have said, covers some five pages, seeks to amend clause 4 of the Bill and to insert a new sub-clause for the purpose of achieving our objective.

As I understand it, the Government itself proposes to amend its own legislation as a result of the work of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to the extent that it has decided to move amendments to clause 4 of this Bill and also amendments to the associated Bill. The Government's proposed amendments will give more flexibility to the responsible Minister in the form of regulations. The Opposition will not oppose them because to a minor degree they do seem to meet some of the objections that have been raised by the Labor Party' s shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, when he very ably debated this matter with the Minister for Transport in the House of Representatives back in May. As the consideration of this piece of legislation was not concluded at the end of the last session, obviously the Government requires that it now be passed by this chamber. In moving our amendment I ask that the Government give serious consideration to it as we have done to its proposed amendments which also were circulated just prior to the commencement of this debate. I seek leave to move my amendments together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of the arguments that Senator Gietzelt put during the consideration of the amendments related to the second reading debate in which he strongly argued the case for improving the base on which indexation of the limits was to be established. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The intention of my major proposals is to incorporate into law the permanent and serious commitment which I believe is necessary in a marriage, to ensure that there are no easy ways out of that commitment and to re-establish quite definitely within the laws of marriage and divorce the concepts of innocence and justice.

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of consolidation, the Attorney-General's amendments are really a serious waste of an opportunity to consolidate the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act. They are both about the same substantial matter. The very first line of the Family Law Act states that it is an Act relating to marriage. The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court excercising jurisdiction under this Act, shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to- (a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

The subsidiary parts of section 43 back up that statement but, as I have said before, nowhere else in the Family Law Act is there anything at all which consolidates marriage as a permanent commitment. Basically, the rest of it provides a mechanism by which marriage can be broken up. That is the scandal of the present Family Law Act. There is very good reason indeed to take stock of the whole matter and consolidate the Marriage Act and the Family Law Act in one piece of legislation.
