TALK.START.PARA: —Once again I thank the Senate. Finally, I feel that if there is to be consolidation it can work only if all of the amendments that I have put forward are incorporated and the principles outlined in the draft are accepted. To some people that may be an entirely too rigid point of view to accept but after my participation in the Family Law Act inquiry I am convinced that it is essential to restore some of the solid provisions that existed prior to the introduction of the family law legislation. Paragraph (b) of my proposed amendment, which seeks the abolition of the Family Court of Australia, would reverse the undesirable trend which has separated the Family Court from the mainstream of Australian jurisprudence. This massive separation was brought about principally as a result of the concept and operation of no fault divorce. It is emphasised by the special conditions of judicial appointment which appear in the Family Law Act. According to the present Act, one must have special sociological qualification before one can be considered for appointment as a judge. My friend Senator Missen, who will oppose me quite strongly when he gets the chance, surely cannot support such conditions. Some of them might preclude him from becoming a judge of the Family Court. It seems to me that this host of novel procedures, rules and practices is not good in the whole field of Australian jurisprudence and that it is necessary to bring family law back under the umbrella of well established Australian jurisprudence.

SPEECH.PARA: My dissenting report to which I have already adverted has made several suggestions about this but I do not intend to trespass on the good nature of the Senate by seeking any more incorporations. The Attorney-General recognises that the present situation presents great difficulties. This, I believe, is an argument for what I am suggesting-the abolition of the Family Court. The very first of the Attorney-General's reference notes states that consultation with four States on an appropriate reference of powers is continuing; that it is unlikely a reference will result in the near future. Why will not the Attorney go the whole hog and try to bring the matter back totally under the umbrella of Australian jurisprudence, recognising the particular functions of the separate States in the matter? Some of my proposals, which have now been incorporated in Hansard, indicate ways in which this can be done. The creation of a family division of the Federal Court involves the satisfying of four or five very simple conditions. The original jurisdiction must be taken care of. That can be done easily enough by amendments. The position of the appellate jurisdiction also can be taken care of by way of simple amendment. The transfer of jurisdiction and the necessary transitional procedures are par for the course to this Parliament, which can have drafted simple amendments to achieve very easily what I have suggested. Not only will my proposals be good for family law, they will also be good for the concept of federation. Much of the worry and concern of individual States, which has contributed to their failure-as the Federal Government keeps reminding us-to refer these powers to the Commonwealth, can be attributed to their natural antipathy to impingment upon and interference with their sovereign rights. I think it is important for us to bear that in mind when considering family law. Always we must consider how this Commonwealth is constructed.

Paragraph (c) of my amendment covers several matters. I refer first of all to the bugbear of having no objective tests for divorce. Much of the pressure for divorce comes from the so-called hard cases which are the cause of special pleadings before the courts. I have always maintained that these are matters of law only and should be dealt with as matters of law, not of sociology. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which my friend Senator Missen is a member-he probably was a member when it looked into this matter-believed that the Family Law Act would bring a degree of honesty and dignity to divorce proceedings, instead of which, as we have seen in examining the short history of this family law and the Family Court, it has created a whole range of new bitternesses and difficulties, particularly in relation to children. I believe that we have to protect marriage from raids by outsiders and I believe that the provisions which I have previously incorporated will tend, in their quite definite attitude to the permanence and the commitment to permanence of a marriage, to give that stability and a consideration of matters of law which in my judgment is not now part of the Family Court.

Many matters associated with annulment were wiped off by the Family Court almost in a couple of sentences. As every honourable senator knows, there is only one ground for separation, for the breaking up of a marriage, and that is the irretriveable breakdown of marriage which is defined as 12 months' separation. That is the only ground for divorce; there are no objective tests. It can create great difficulty for those who wish an annulment. Some people have religious problems with annulment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that if it is not an objective test?

—I do not have time, Senator. It is necessary for me to stay with my own propositions; I will have to discuss your propositions privately. It is impossible for people of several religious persuasions in this country to have their marriages broken up because in many cases the only way those marriages can be broken up is by annulment. Of course annulment is the statement by an authority-a court in some instances, church authorities in others-that the marriage is null and void. There are no adequate provisions in the Family Law Act now to cover that and it is one of the reasons for consolidation. I would like to cover an enormous number of other things but time does not permit it. But I think that a fair and objective examination of what I propose will lead to a better Family Law Act in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite difficult to believe that Senator Martyr is serious about the amendments that he placed before us in relation to the Family Law Act. We have read his dissenting report to the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, so we know he is not joking. We are also very well aware of the fact that he makes considerable use of the terms ' innocence' and 'objectivity' and, by inference, guilt and subjectivity. This evening, on a previous occasion and certainly during the inquiry into the Family Law Act these terms were thrown about with gay abandon by the honourable senator . I could not get him to define innocence 'when I gave evidence to the joint select' inquiry and I still do not know what he means. I suggest that an innocent, in his terms, might be shocked and horrified rather than amazed by the grounds for amendment that he suggests. They cover an amazing range of so-called evils as laid down in his dissenting report and in his amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: To remind honourable senators, I will go through just a few of them. In his terms, annulment would be allowed if either party were not of full age, if there were mistaken identify, if either party were suffering from communicable venereal disease unknown to the other party, if either party were not of sufficiently sound mind or if one party had been or was actively engaged in homosexual activity. If this was intended to be a comprehensive catalogue of evils within the honourable senator's definition, I suggest that it is not a particularly comprehensive list and that he has left out a few things which I think might quite reasonably be included. Are we to understand that the honourable senator actually approves of some of the things he has omitted such as incest, pederasty, sodomy and sado masochism? One could go on all night, but perhaps no more is needed to indicate the ridiculous nature of some of the amendments suggested by the honourable senator.

There has been a considerable amount of reference, too, to the sanctity of marriage. I have attended with great care the arguments of those who believe genuinely that clause 41 will somehow lessen the gravity with which people regard the dissolution of marriage. This, if I may recall, for the benefit of honourable senators, is the clause which would allow that final decision, a decree nisi, to be delivered without the attendance of either of the parties or of their legal representatives. This line of argument also includes frequently an allusion to the sanctity of marriage and I believe this assumes that the majority of Australians attach deep religious significance to the marriage ceremony. However, the statement of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) read at the opening of the Opas Memorial Library on 6 February 1982 by the Honourable Neil Brown included the statement: 'traditional moral and religious values have been rejected by a large section of the community'.

I believe that this is clearly shown by the rapid acceptance of marriage by a celebrant as an alternative to the religious ceremony. In the 1950s and 1960s the annual average percentage of marriages celebrated by ministers of religion was in the high 80s, nearly 90 per cent. Since 1975 this has dropped markedly and in 1980 it was 63.7 per cent. I appreciate the fact that most of those who have divorced under the provision of the Family Law Act of 1975 were married in a church, initially for a variety of reasons, many of which had nothing to do with religious conviction. Many of them had to do with the opportunity to get dressed up and to be photographed in a rather pretty setting, not to mention church marriages for the sake of pacifying relations. One has every respect, of course, for the opinions of those for whom such life crises as birth, death and marriage need this extra element of supernatural sanction, but there is no justification in fact for extrapolating this belief to the whole community, especially in a not very religious country such as Australia. There is even less justification for using this as a reason for insisting that a decree nisi should not be issued except in the presence of the applicant or applicant's counsel.

I believe that this particular amendment is eminently sensible. It acknowledges that at this point in many applications for dissolution there remains only the formality of issuing the decree, and valuable time and resources can be saved for the benefit of other less far advanced cases. It acknowledges too that the expense to the parties of another court appearance cannot be justified in the circumstances enumerated by the clause. Women, the majority of applicants, are particularly at a disadvantage because of their lower earning capacity and legal aid is not generally available for dissolution. If the applicant is domiciled in a rural town, and engages a local solicitor, the costs, including the costs of travel-for example, from places such as Esperance or Kununurra to Perth-can be considerable. Surely it is for the applicant to decide whether some psychological benefit is to be derived from attendance at the last rites, the analogy used by those who advocate compulsory attendance at such ceremonies. Where the emotional ties and conflicts remain unresolved observance at a brief hearing, although an expensive one, is unlikely to heal the scars and it should not be presumed that it is an adequate or sufficient substitute for the long term counselling and support which may be necessary.

Examination of the details of those marriages of the 1950s and 1960s which constitute the majority of those marriages which have been the subject of the 1975-80 divorce applications indicates some of the reasons for the increased incidence which is erroneously attributed to the introduction of the no-fault Act. The increase in the proportion of teenage marriages in those two decades has been an important factor in the upward trend, such early marriage being demonstrably subject to a high risk of breakdown. Page 47 of volume 2 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act states:

. . . of the dissolutions granted in 1977, 11.7 per cent of husbands and 40.7 per cent of wives were married before age 20 years and the proportions were only slightly lower in the early seventies. The combination of youth of both parties, premarital pregnancy and relatively low income status of the husband seems to have offered the greatest threat to the survival of marriage.

More counselling at the time of potential dissolution is apparently having its effect and the improved success rate is commendable and encouraging. An equally or more valuable use of funds would be comprehensive and formalised premarriage counselling and information as advocated by both the Family Law Council and the Joint Select Committee and, I am happy to hear, also Senator Martyr. Marriage aspirants should be informed of the legal and social implications of being married and each given a written summary of rights and responsibilities of married persons. Some of us look forward to the day when such premarital procedures include defined property rights of husbands and wives which, when introduced, will help to reduce the length of hearings, long delays, high costs and the resentment which accumulates against the process of law which currently characterise too many property settlements.
On the question of indicators of breakdown of marriage, page 35 of Volume 2 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, states:

Mr Harvey from the Attorney-General's Department, suggested that the number of deserted wives is a more accurate measure of instability than divorce rates and that, if there were fewer deserted wives but more divorces, it would follow that there was a better sorting out of relationships.

Unfortunately our culture prefers to cling to old myths about fairy-tale romances, the future wreathed in tulle and orange blossom and suffused by a rosy glow. Expectations in too many instances are quite unreal and if they were ever real, which I doubt, they are now totally outmoded. There is little understanding of the legal position or changing social patterns and trends. Examination of data from earlier decades shows what dramatic changes have occurred in family patterns. Late age at marriage and high proportions of people who have never married, especially amongst men, contrasts with almost universal and comparatively very early marriage in recent decades. Early in the twentieth century women bore their families over the length of their productive years, the last pregnancy usually occurring in their forties so that a woman still had a child to care for during her fifties and she rarely attained her seventieth birthday. It was truly an adult life spent bearing and rearing children. Of course, she would work to supplement her husband's income, but rarely outside of the home or of the immediate neighbourhood.

The woman of the 1960s and 1970s has married much younger-the median age has been between 21 and 22 since 1951-but many have postponed their childbearing until their late twenties, restricted their family size to two or three children and by age 35 or 40 are embarking upon another 25 years of productive rather than reproductive life. The opportunity to obtain paid employment outside of the home has undoubtedly been a factor in providing the sense of economic independence as an alternative to marriage which has gone sour or which has not lived up to expectations. Dr Holger Stub, a researcher in social gerontology at Temple University in Philadelphia, is quoted in an article in the West Australian of 25 November 1981 as saying:
You have to take a realistic view of the emotional toll of longevity on marriage.
Longer lives mean more time for strains to develop in marriage and, consequently, more divorces.
Increased longevity also allows men and women virtually to bargain for two marriages-one for the young family years and one for the post-parental period.
Though this sounds amoral to romantics or the religiously-oriented, it is not merely a possibility but is actually taking place.
The article continues:
And, while this introduces a certain chilly planned obsolescence into marital relationships, it may indeed, he says, become a trend.
Two categories of divorce have increased in recent years-couples with young children and older couples who have been married 20 or more years.
'Longevity', says Dr Stub, ''has added as much as a quarter of a century of close living to many marriages.
'The high level of insight, good fortune and adaptable personality required to have a 50-year marriage are, as yet, not too plentiful among applicants for marriage licences.

Despite the moralising and obsession with innocence and guilt still discernible in the written and spoken declarations of some of our colleagues, I am assured that in a majority of cases which are currently in the course of dissolution there is no third party involved. Even where the purpose of a dissolution is to establish a fresh liaison only the most harsh and hidebound would, I suggest, seriously argue for regression to divorce based on fault or on narrow sectarian prejudice.

Referring to another amendment which is before us, I believe that attaching the power of arrest to injunctions is a welcome addition to the Act, providing substance and credibility to its stature in the eyes of those who are most at risk of violence and those who seek to protect them. Maureen Kingshot, in a paper prepared for the Labor Women's Conference in January 1982, said:

Vexatious litigants, judge murderers, and policemen who don't want to know about injunctions against domestic violence still exist, and continue as a symbol of the Family Court's struggle to exert its authority and have itself taken seriously, as part of our ordinary court system.

Unfortunately, the notion still exists in the community that a man owns his wife and family and has the right to vent upon them the anger and frustration for which he perceives no other outlet. We have seen the recent extraordinary approach of the senior counsellor of the Family Court, Mr McKenzie, who sought support from trade unions for his opposition to hand over facilities, suggesting as he did that much domestic violence was engendered by passive women exercising their lack of influence, thus provoking physical attack. His distorted view has been totally rejected by the Chief Judge of the Family Court and also by the Director of the Institute of Family Studies, the latter having, I believe, requested that the individual concerned be asked to relinquish his committee position on the Family Law Council.

Finally, as a Western Australian, I draw to the attention of honourable senators the position of the judges of the Western Australian Family Court, who had been collectively guaranteed appointment to the Australian family law appeal court. They are angry and disappointed that only one of their number has been so appointed. The historic and geographic isolation of Western Australia makes it particularly desirable that Western Australian judges be afforded the opportunity of participation in the national appeal process and that they should be also able to contribute to the development of family law, which development is at present seen as the sole province of the dreaded eastern States. If some decision has already been made that the integration process is to stop with the appointment of Mr Justice Barblett to the Australian family law appeal court, I request that the matter be urgently reconsidered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the second reading stage of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981. During this debate members of this chamber will express their personal views-the views which are the basis of their experience and the representations that have been made to them over many years concerning the operations of the Famly Law Act. It is significant that at least we are now reaching a point at which perhaps the second reading stage of this Bill may be concluded and we will commence the more important stage, the Committee stage, at which we shall deal with a considerable mass of amendments which are before the Parliament already.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth reminding ourselves that consideration of the Bill has taken a very leisurely course. In July 1980 the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, consisting of members from both Houses of Parliament, on which I had the honour to serve, reported to Parliament. It made a number of important recommendations- I think in all 72, of which 27 found their way into the Attorney-General's Bill. On the basis of the discussion of that Bill many others may be considered as well. The Government announced its views on dealing with the Bill. This is not a Government Bill except in the sense that it is presented by the Government. But, of course it involves matters on which traditionally all members of parliament exercise their own judgments. We have had a debate which commenced on 20 October 1981 and resumed on 16 and 24 March of this year, and now tonight it resumes again.

It is an important debate on a very important subject, because, in my view, the Family Law Act 1975 was the single most significant and valuable social reform of the 1970s. It managed to make a very dramatic difference to family law arrangements in Australia. It updated them a degree which had long been thought impossible. We have really started leading the world-truly we can say that we have done that-in the way in which the Family Court of Australia has operated and in the various other machinery provisions which have been provided in that legislation. I say, as one who served on the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which likewise made a full investigation of the Bill in 1974-most of its recommendations were adopted by the Parliament; unfortunately, not quite all of them-that the Parliament, in adopting that Bill, showed by the solid majority of people who supported a change in family law, that there were great expectations for improvement.

I believe that the results of the massive committee report that I have before me, based on 15 months of investigation and involving a great number of expert witnesses, vindicates and justifies the general system of family law which we adopted in 1975. We conducted an examination very soon after that Bill came into operation. We did it in the absence at that time of the Insitute of Family Studies which has, unfortunately, commenced operation only in recent years. But with those limitations, I think that there was sufficient evidence for the great majority of the Committee to come down solidly in favour of the operation of the Court and, while making a number of useful proposals and suggested amendments, to come to a conclusion that the ground of divorce based on irretrievable breakdown proved by one year's separation was indeed adequate.

Senator Martyr asked why there was not an objective test. I must assure him that there is nothing more objective as a test than one year's separation. That is an objective test. It was recommended to the Parliament at that time and was adopted by it. It is in the law and in no way is it recommended by the Joint Committee that it should be changed. I make one other reference to Senator Martyr's views expressed earlier. He says that this is just a matter of law, and not a matter of social need or sociology. I could not disagree more with that view. The whole family law situation is not just a matter of law. Laws are important for society, and it is important that they be clear and effective. But there is a great deal more to family law than that, and the whole operation of the Family Court, which is based on unit operation, on the use of experts and on the need for conciliation, counselling and so forth, covers a great deal more than merely setting up a system of law.

Senator Martyr and some others who are critics of the system talk about the restoration of guilt and innocence. I do not propose to go into those worn out concepts to any degree tonight. As one who practised in the family law area for many years-when we passed the Bill in 1975 I think that I was the one practising lawyer in this area serving in the Parliament-I can say that one does not want to return in any way to that area of guilt and innocence, to the ridiculous waste of money and time and of people's lives that was based upon trying to prove whether someone was guilty of some offence. Guilt was always spread between the parties. Guilt and innocence were useless concepts and only did damage, particularly to the lives of children.

Since that time, fortunately, we have had the opportunity to see in practice what has been done. I do not intend tonight to go into all the details of the operations of this Bill or the Act as it stands. Senator Evans, in a speech in March of this year, dealt comprehensively with the area covered by the Bill. With the exception of statements which he has made on open courts and publication of proceedings-on which I stand strongly in disagreement-I am in total agreement with him.

I say again that the Joint Committee report adopted in 1980 was a vindication of the no fault system as adopted-that we would hereafter determine that divorces would be granted if one year's separation occurred, and that we would not seek to find the faults of the parties. We set up the Family Court to operate this system, with specialist judges who have been appointed, with particular interests and knowledge in these areas. By and large, although perhaps with some exceptions, we have found dedicated, valuable, excessively hard-working judges who have performed an enormous amount of valuable work in the community since that time. But in addition to that many experts have been used in the court. The conciliation and counselling that takes place and the use of deputy registrars to look at the financial affairs of parties to try as far as possible to eliminate a great deal of conflict have been valuable. The report , which I urge everyone to read, shows the justification.

In the course of the Committee's deliberations about 200 individuals made submissions. There were many more than that-700 or 800 altogether-but about 200 individuals had complaints about the way in which their cases had been handled. Of course, it was not possible for the Committee to examine these cases in detail. It would not have been possible, because the Committee would have had to examine what the other parties had to say about the situation and to ask the judges how they reflected on the whole matter. That, of course, was not possible . However, the significant thing about the 200 cases is that at that time 200, 000 people had been through the Family Court, and of the 200,000, 0.1 per cent, or about 200 people, chose to put criticisms before the Committee. The significance is in the numbers.

The problems which the Committee found were quite considerable, because apart from the desire that we had to create a system which would cover all family law matters, unfortunately it is still the position today that that unity of jurisdiction does not exist. I lay the blame essentially on a number of State governments over the years that have failed to do the obvious-to refer power to the Court to deal with the custody of ex-nuptial children-not legitimate children. They should be dealt with within the same Court and receive the same type of justice. That fundamental absence of justice is not due to any fault on the part of the Courts themselves. It lies essentially at the doors of the State governments, which have dilly-dallied for years and have refused the request of the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth to surrender the powers which are of no use to them but which lead to people going from one court to another obtaining separate determinations in respect of their children. The same problem arises in respect of property matters, where people may have to jump from court to court- State court or Federal court-depending on whether divorce proceedings have been commenced. Again, the States have failed to surrender those powers. It is a wicked situation which has caused perhaps millions of dollars of loss to people. A great deal of hardship must be laid at the doors of State governments for their neglect in regard to these matters.

When this Act came into operation the divorce figures showed an early rise. This caused the Jeremiahs in our midst-some of them quite close to me here-to be very unhappy. Marriages could break down; the floodgates would be opened; divorce rates would go up tremendously, and so forth. In the first year of operation of the Act the figure went up to 69,000. People had only to look at the previous figures to see what happens when a substantial change is made to the divorce law. People tend to hold back, to wait for the new law. They do not proceed until it comes into operation. The figure went up to 69,000 and then went down to under 40,000. The figure is now rising again slowly, in accord with the growth in the divorce rate which is to be found in most Western societies. There has been a change in society's views and in the wishes of the people which have led to some increase in divorce over the years. The Family Law Act was not responsible for that.

The people who criticise this Act constantly ignore the difference between the divorce rate and the marriage breakdown rate. As Senator Coleman, who was the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, and I realise, and the experts indicated this to the Committee, the breakdown rate has been fairly constant throughout society . There have been people who could not divorce, people who had to continue living together or stay separated, unable to remarry or create new families. Of course, that is the fundamental figure about which we are concerned, not the divorce rate. We have seen fall away the hysteria which was apparent immediately after the Act came into operation. Speaking of hysteria, I turn to my colleague Senator Martyr, who sits next to me. With the greatest degree of kindness in the world, I think that, unfortunately, he is afflicted with the problems of the Bourbons, who learnt nothing and forgot nothing. I am afraid that Senator Martyr now girds his loins to fight again this general question, as of course he and others fought it in 1974. Having lost that battle and the battle on the Bill they are proceeding--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit hard, isn't it?
—I have not finished yet, Senator. I have not said anything yet. I want to be a little more critical of Senator Martyr.
—And we will be back again and again and again.

—Yes, I know we will. The honourable senator will be back again and again and again. I hope that he will continue to have an audience. So far as the Committee is concerned, I was disappointed that Senator Martyr did not come back again and again and again because he gave up the Committee some months before it finished its deliberations.
—That's not true.

—He did not attend any Committee meeting while we deliberated on the report. For a period of months he decided to boycott the Committee. Other Committee members who put in dissenting reports and held strong views which were critical of the report took part in the deliberations. Unfortunately, we had to suffer the complete absence of Senator Martyr while we deliberated on our report .
—I told you that I was going to dissent and I did.
—Yes, Senator Martyr dissented. I and a lot of other people dissented on certain matters.
—Not totally.

—Not totally, that is right, but the honourable senator did not even give us the benefit of his wisdom when we came to deliberate on this report as a Committee of the Parliament. I believe that was regrettable. What is even more regrettable--
—Hopeless, too.
—Senator Martyr said that the Committee was hopeless.
—No, it was hopeless to dissent.

—I do not think it is hopeless to dissent. Senator Coleman and I, who dissented on other matters, do not agree. We think it is important for people to express their views. I do not object for one moment to Senator Martyr' s right to dissent. What I do object to is that when he put in a dissenting report he distorted the words of an Act of the Parliament of this nation. I will now read from page 225 of the report in which Senator Martyr dissented. I could also be reading here tonight the article which he recently wrote to the Institute of Public Affairs of New South Wales in which he repeated the same mistake. Senator Martyr stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference of the Joint Select Committee of the Family Law Act give no definition of 'the institution of marriage', but there was general acceptance among the Inquiry of the definition of marriage contained in S.43 of the Family Law Act, which is as follows . . .
This is the quotation which he gave as appearing to come from section 43 of the Family Law Act but from which it does not come:

''The relation which exists between a man and woman to the exclusion of all others which is voluntarily and publicly entered into and which is intended to last for their joint lives, to afford them mutual help, comfort and support, and to protect and promote the welfare of the children of them, and each of them.''

In his dissenting report and in the article Senator Martyr has written, in which he based his argument upon that quotation, nearly all the words which he quoted do not appear in that so-called definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do.

—I ask the honourable sentor to wait for just a moment. That is not a definition of marriage. The definition of marriage is found in the Marriage Act. The needs for marriage and so on are found there. Section 43 sets out the principles that ought to be applied by the court in relation to its dealing with matters including marriage. What one sees when one looks at section 43 as to what the court is required to have regard to-this is what Senator Martyr is referring to-is the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life. It is nothing more than that. There is no reference in that so-called quotation of Senator Martyr's of marriage being publicly entered into or for the partners to afford mutual help, comfort, protection, support and so on. If Senator Martyr would argue like that in a formal document and then repeat it in a published document to the Institute of Public Affairs, to which I have now replied, then I am afraid that very little credence can be given to his argument. The only matter in his speech with which I can agree is the fact that the law does influence behaviour. He said that in a speech on another occasion and I agree with him. The law does influence behaviour, but it does not determine what people do in life. It is an important influence, and a good family law is an important and valuable influence on behaviour in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall turn from the martyrdom which Senator Martyr has made of the Act to deal with what we are doing in regard to this Bill. We are providing here running repairs on the operation of the Act. As a Committee we found certain defects, certain things which will work better if we change them. As a Committee we were concerned at the delays which take place in the courts and we made recommendations about this. Fortunately, in the period since the Committee sat, more court cousellors and deputy registrars have been appointed. At the Melbourne Registry, which was one of the worst affected by delays-this was a serious matter for litigants-the delays have been greatly decreased. I believe that for undefended divorces there is now a delay of about six weeks or eight weeks and for defended cases the period is usually six months to eight months or so. A great deal of improvement has occurred in the operation of the law since then.

One of the matters I dealt with in my dissenting report-I will not table it, but I hope that honourable senators will read it because it deals with certain things about which I thought the Committee needed to be stronger-concerns a reference to the attitude of lawyers which early in the operation of the Act was inadequate. I wish to quote a reference on page 206 of the Committee's report to remarks made by Mr Justice Butler. In relation to the approaches adopted in the early stages by judges as well as other lawyers under the Family Law Act Mr Justice Butler stated:

However, if the attitude is adopted that lawyers have no need of sociological approaches, but simply need to know the law and to adopt a forensic stance which is no different from that in other courts, then we have made no progress-the legal profession spells the beginning of its own end in the family law jurisdiction.
Fortunately I think one can say that there has been great improvement there, that lawyers and other experts have specialised in and are now knowledgeable in this area.

The Bill that is before us-the Attorney-General's Bill-incorporates, as I said, some 27 of the recommendations of the Committee. I think one may say that one of the highlights is that the Government is now proposing to use all the constitutional powers that it believes it has. It will stretch the custody and property powers to the extent that they can go. It may be that it will fall foul of the High Court of Australia which, regrettably, has done a fair amount of damage, I think, to the operation of family law in some of its rulings in recent years. But we would hope that these powers will be upheld in the High Court and that will therefore mitigate the deficiencies which the States have imposed upon us.

Under the recommendations in the Bill there will be less requirement of attendance at courts. Of course, there was a certain amount of hysteria earlier on by some people who thought that this was divorce by post and things of that sort. This Bill will allow divorce without court attendance. But of course for years that has been the position, that the only requirement necessary is an attendance by a lawyer on behalf of one of the parties. There is no requirement necessarily of the parties to be there. The paper work, the details, the investigation and whether the children are properly being attended to are matters which are dealt with well before the matter comes before the court and the saving to people of expense which is proposed by the Attorney-General's draft will be very valuable. We should certainly avoid any hysteria on the idea that we must have a parade of parties or, as Senator Shirley Walters wants, all the parties, to attend the hearing so that a great deal of expense and difficulty will occur unless the judge excuses someone from attendance. I find her amendment in this respect quite unsatisfactory also. I think it would be a very backward step so far as the courts are concerned.

The Attorney's Bill also strengthens the injunction power so that it will be protective particularly of wives who are suffering bashings or who are unable to get protection. At the moment there are difficulties about this and the proposals are sensible ones. It also overcomes something which unfortunately has been in the Bill since 1975-despite the attempts of the Senate committee in 1974 -and that is the requirement that the wishes of 14-year-old children have to be observed; at some magic stage when they reach 14 years of age their wishes have to be observed. Before that they were just taken into account. Now there is a general provision that all such wishes will be taken into account by the court but the court will be left with the fundamental discretion.

Finally, among the major highlights of the Attorney's Bill, are the provisions which will help with regard to people's rights to superannuation. People will not find that because they are divorced now and their marriage is severed the rights they have also worked for-perhaps as a wife to help and support her husband for years-will disappear so that in three years he will be entitled to a great lump sum of superannuation and she will be entitled to nothing and he will be able to get away with it. These provisions which are made at the moment to allow the adjournment of these applications for longer periods will, I think, do greater justice to people in the future.

Briefly, I have quite a number of amendments which I will be moving in the course of this debate. It is important that after all this delay we get the best Act that we can now and that we do not just take some amendments and then come back next year. We have seen how difficult it is to get the Parliament to turn itself to consideration of these matters. Among the amendments which I will be moving are some 11 which have been drafted on behalf of the Chairman of the Committee, Mr Phillip Ruddock. These are recommendations which were in the Joint Committee report but which were not picked up in the Attorney's Bill. They are recommendations which will promote the early settlement of cases so that they will not drag on, with great cost to the parties. It is important that settlements should not be forced on people because they do not have legal aid but it is important also that every attempt should be made to settle claims at an early stage.

Provision will be sought to be made through amendments that will be moved to protect a child following the death of that child's sole custodian. The provision will be that in such an event the child will automatically be made a ward of the court.

As the Committee recommended, proposals will be presented for criteria to be set out for custody decisions. At the moment criteria in regard to maintenance and other matters are set out in the Act. However, when determining custody the court is left very much at large. Of course it is concerned to decide what is in the best interests of the children, but no guide is given to it that it should take into account certain matters. The Committee felt that these should be specified as at least guidelines in the Act and we will try to do so. There are amendments which will seek to reduce litigation in regard to custody. Long drawn out custody cases and constant returns to the Court are some of the real bugbears of the system and have been for many years. This is a course of great expense to the parties and the Commonwealth and is a course of great anguish for children.

I will also move an amendment in respect of the way in which Commonwealth departments should disclose information that they have about the whereabouts of a child. There are difficulties in getting this information now. I think it is high time that Commonwealth departments, under proper supervision and with proper respect for people's privacy, should give this information which is in their possession. There is also an amendment proposing the annual review of child maintenance which, of course, as a result of inflation ought to change more regularly otherwise people must go back to court at great expense to achieve what they seek.

The other amendments that I will move include some which were suggested by the Family Law Committee of the Australian Law Council. They mainly seek to overcome practice defects and, I think, would be sensible and valuable improvements on the Bill. Likewise the Family Law Council has suggested a number of amendments, some of which are picked up in the more recent amendments which the Attorney- General has tabled. However, there are others, particularly in relation to the principles that ought to operate in this Act. Conciliation and readjustment, not just reconciliation, should be part of the aims of the Act. What the Court does mostly is not just reconcile people who have fallen apart. That is not something the Court can generally do. It is important that it conciliates to reduce the amount of friction and help people readjust their lives.

I think Family Court judges also have cause for complaint. I hope to move an amendment regarding their emoluments. I want to see the restoration of the level of their remuneration to that of the Federal Court judges' scale which they were on but from which they have slipped. We must consider that matter and also whether there should be an appeals division which is proposed in the Government' s Bill. There is a great deal of criticism from Family Court judges-I think with some value-of this proposal.

The important matters in this debate are not once more those which were considered in 1974. Surely the purpose is not to fight the Family Law Act and the system-the 1974 show. That would fly entirely in the face of the bulk of evidence and the recommendations of the Joint Committee. Of course what will be debated substantially-I will not go into details on this aspect-is the question of open courts which the Committee, by a majority, recommended. I and a number of others were not happy with that proposal. It is a question whether one believes in publicity, freedom of information perhaps in regard to the Family Court, overriding privacy which, in this area, I think is important. But more important than open courts is the question of publication. This Bill contains proposals which I regard as quite crazy. They are ones under which anybody with any ingenuity, who in the past through the gutter Press tried to deride people, will operate with a great deal of ease. I hope the Bill, with suitable amendments, will pass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I join in the debate on the second reading of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981 out of concern for the future of marriage and families in our society and the widespread implications of the legislation. In doing so let me say at the outset that it is not through any lack of compassion or understanding for those in our community who are in the unfortunate position of going through divorce or custody proceedings that I wish to raise some doubts about the proposed changes. Indeed, since the whole matter came up for discussion people with every viewpoint on this issue have come to see me. Divorce is a time-consuming, emotionally draining and financially taxing procedure. I can appreciate that those involved would want to reduce these factors as much as possible. However, more than the considerations of cost cutting and time saving is involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Law Act 1975, which came into operation on 5 January 1976, made a major change in the law relating to divorce by providing that the sole ground for divorce in Australia was to be the irretrievable breakdown of marriage, the proof of which was to rest only on 12 months' separation of the parties preceding the date of the filing of the application. To quote the words of the then Attorney-General Senator Lionel Murphy, the reason for this was:
. . . to eliminate as far as possible, the high costs, the delays, and indignities experienced by so many parties to divorce proceedings, under the existing Matrimonial Causes Act.

The Family Law Act proposed to buttress the stability of marriage and encourage reconciliation. The more popular understanding, however, was that it was passed to make divorce easier. As Senator Missen said, the number of divorces rose from 24,307 in 1975 to 63,267 in 1976, after one year of operation of the Act. Of course, we acknowledge that one contributing factor for the increase in divorces in 1976 was the backlog which built up before the implementation of the new Act. I guess people thought that when the new Act came in they would take advantage of the more acceptable provisions. There was a gradual drop in the number of divorces each year after that until 1980. In that year the number of divorces granted exceeded by 1,404 those of 1979.

No one would deny that the institution of marriage and the family unit have undergone significant changes over time, by demographic changes on the one hand and economic, social and technological changes on the other. Furthermore, the degree of responsibility which the so-called welfare state has taken upon itself for support of the family has taken some of the pressure off the marriage partners and opened up new material possibilities, such as housing, security of income, health, education, day care for pre-schoolers and the prospect for women particularly of greater participation in the labour force with the psychological and financial benefits that come with it. All of this has contributed in no small way to a lessening of the strength of the family unit. Today people are becoming more and more concerned at the incidence of marriage and family breakdown. Indeed some submissions to the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act showed that people believed that the Act actually encourages them to look upon marriage as a temporary arrangement, with no commitment to permanency.

I was sorry to hear Senator Giles quote a statement by the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) indicating that he felt the traditional moral and religious values had been rejected. I feel that is probably why so many marriages are breaking up. According to the Family Foundation of Victoria the Act discourages the commitment necessary for marriage to flourish. The Catholic welfare organisation, Centacare, asserts that legislation itself affects community standards, that the law is so phrased that for many people it becomes moral law and that civil law generally becomes a standard of behaviour. Women's Action Alliance feels that the legislation counters the stabilising influence on marriage which it believes is Parliament's role to maintain. I believe there is truth in the notion that one can reach a point where making a practice easier actually promotes the practice. I also believe that clause 41 of the proposed amendments actually reaches that point in relation to divorce. It makes the dissolution of marriage a mere bureaucratic process. I disagree with Senator Missen in that I believe that, as we have witnesses to a marriage, there ought to be somebody there when we are dissolving a marriage. It should not be a case of just writing in and getting a divorce.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why? The marriage has already broken down. That is after the event.
—I think we ought to try to give people training in trying to keep marriages together.
—You have to do that before the marriage breaks down. Afterwards is too late.
—That is unfortunate. I feel sorry that a lot more people do not go in for counselling before the marriage breaks down.
—I could not agree with you more, but that does not mean that they have to appear in court.

—I think it is not just a case of divorce by post. I do not like it at all. The Anglican Archbishops of Australia have a valid point to make in their comments on this part of the proposed amendments. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: Marriage is not simply a private arrangement between two individuals. It is also a public act, significant for the community. The law recognises this by requiring the presence at a marriage of an authorised celebrant and at least two witnesses.
This bears out what I said before. The statement continues:
It is indeed regrettable when a marriage ends in divorce, but if a divorce does occur, it is no less a public act than the act of marrying.
Indeed, if there are children of the marriage, the act of divorcing may have even more important public significance than the original act of marrying.

To my way of thinking there is something very superficial and short term about the concept of sparing parties the trauma of separation proceedings. Whether by death or divorce, separation is a painful experience but the grief has to be accepted and dealt with. I believe that the solemnity of marriage demands that clause 41-proposed section 98A, which relates to divorce by post-is not passed into law.

There are many aspects of the proposed changes which are to be commended, particularly changes in relation to the settling of maintenance and property issues, including the right of a party to share in the former husband's superannuation or other such benefits when they become available. These provisions should prevent financial hardship in many cases and allow for greater justice in the settlement. Likewise, the amendments relating to children have generally made provision for their welfare in a way which the existing Act has failed to do. However, whilst I commend some of the provisions of the 1982 Amendment Bill, I feel sorry about the fact that no attempt has been made to restore the dignity of marriage and to safeguard the stability of marriage. I make specific reference here to clause 18 of the Bill relative to section 48 of the principal Act. No mention has been made of any change in the grounds for the dissolution of marriage. Indeed, the single no fault, year's separation continues as the sole ground for the dissolution of the marriage contract. Senator Missen said there was no way in the world that that would not remain as it is now.

It is my belief that this is not in the interests of marriage and the family and that, indeed, the separation period could be extended to two years. Too often these days couples are inadequately prepared to enter into a permanent commitment and, being aware of the present legislation, look on marriage as a temporary arrangement which is easily terminated. Since the Family Law Act was enacted in 1975 over 300,000 children have been affected by divorce in their families. Many of these victims will be ill-prepared to enter into a stable marriage when the occasion arises unless provision is made for them to receive more adequate marriage preparation and, when appropriate, premarital counselling .

The Catholic Family Welfare Bureau in Brisbane has provided marriage counsellors for the Family Court since its inception and has been in a unique position to study the effects of the legislation. It has found that greater stability in marriage can be ensured only through requiring more adequate preparation for those entering marriage and by making divorce less readily available. I therefore think, as I said earlier, that much more energy and legislative thrust should be put into providing more adequate marriage preparation and premarriage counselling.

In conclusion, I would like to say that we, as elected representatives of the people of this nation, and indeed all Australians should consider carefully the changing face of marriage and ultimately divorce. Are we giving enough care and consideration to the future of the institution of marriage and to the children who are the victims of broken marriages? In our endeavours to reduce costs and minimise emotional trauma, are we not contributing to the ultimate demise of that which we are supposedly trying to help-that is, the family unit? I feel that marriage is much more than a legal contract. It involves both a personal and social commitment and should not be dissolved without ensuring that both parties have the opportunity to be present and to be heard. I do not think that we want to think of marriage just as being a temporary arrangement-and that, I am afraid, is what some of the amendments to the Act might bring about.

The opportunity for obtaining a decree of dissolution of marriage by the presentation of false affidavit evidence ought not to be widened, and to allow this to happen on the basis of eliminating the cost of personal attendance of an applicant who conducts his own application at the hearing-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the case. You want to read the clause. It is where it is an undisputed case where both parties agree that the marriage has broken down. All we are saying in this amendment is that those people should not have to have the added expense of going into court; that they can have it done just by making an application.

—I thought I made it clear when I spoke earlier that my opinion was quite different, and that is exactly the way I feel. As I said earlier, and the Anglican bishops agreed with me, if you have a celebrant for a marriage as well as witnesses it seems to me that if the marriage is dissolved-
—What, that you should have witnesses there?

—That is quite right. So I feel this practice would devalue and denigrate the institution of marriage and the family. As a senator trying in this place to safeguard the interests of the Australian family I do not believe that is right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes remaining for debate tonight I wish to commence my remarks on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981. The Bill is particularly important as the first comprehensive review of the 1975 Family Law Act. It follows a thorough investigation of the Act and its operation by the parliamentary Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act which reported in 1980. Additionally, there have been the annual reports of the Family Law Council, which was set up to make recommendations to the Attorney-General concerning the workings of the Act on an ongoing basis. The Bill takes up certain of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee and others of the Family Law Council. In some cases, provsions of the Bill have the support of both the Committee and the Council.

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading debate I intend to put to the Senate my attitude to the provisions of the Bill as they relate to the views I hold on the subject of family law generally and the Family Law Act in particular. Those views I have formulated as a practitioner of the former Matrimonial Causes Act and from daily contact with practitioners of the Family Law Act. Under provisions of the Marriage Act, the celebrant is called upon to state to the parties:
Marriage according to law in Australia is the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life.

Section 43 of the Family Law Act similarly obliges the Family Court Act of Australia in the exercise of its jurisdiction to have regard to the need to preserve and protect the instititution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life. Unless we wish to challenge that basic premise it must be the starting point of any family law debate and it is a premise with which I have no quarrel.

Closely related is the obligation of the Family Court under the same provision to have regard to the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly when it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children. Again, I support that objective. The proposal for the Family Court of Australia was the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which was assisted by a paper entitled 'An Australian Family Court' written by Mr R. Watson, Q.C., as he then was. In it he said:

If the family is the linchpin of a civilised society, the preservation and protection of marriage is a constantly sought goal of a good society. Therefore, marriage breakdown, particularly in its effect on children, is seen as a social ill to be prevented if possible.

So, marriage at law has a meaning but the institution of marriage goes much further. It goes to the exchange of vows and the moral consequences of breach of those vows. It goes to the role of the family as a linchpin of our society and to the responsibility of the community to offer it the widest possible protection and assistance. It is the relationship between the institution of marriage, with all the social connotations of that expression, and the responsibilities of the statute law of Australia insofar as it should play a part in the support of that institution that raises such deep public debate and concern.

Marriage is not a contract in the normal legal meaning as attached to that expression. Our law does not provide that upon marriage the parties shall be deemed to have entered into some form of contract covering their relationship with each other, the offspring of the marriage, or the property of the parties to the marriage. It is not a contract capable of being enforced by legal action and that, upon a breach, a party to which has some right of action. Marriage at law does, however, have consequences at law. Such consequences reflect what the community expects of marriage and what it sees as the responsibility of marriage . For example, the community has traditionally seen marriage as a life-long institution. It has not, therefore, been prepared to accept dissolution at the will of the parties. The community has, however, evolved to the view that where there has been an irreconcilable breakdown-where the fabric of the marriage has been lost and all that remains is the legal tie-there should be a procedure at law whereby the legal tie can be severed. Furthermore, the community sees a responsibility of married persons to children of the marriage. This is reflected in the law that they should be responsible for the care and maintenance of those children until otherwise determined by law.

It can be argued that the law should go further and specifically regulate marriage between the parties and their obligations to each other. This is certainly a possibility which is open and in the case of some jurisdictions with marriage contracts and principle of community of property it has, in fact, gone that far. It is from the ecclesiastical laws and the notion of breach of vows or breach of obligations of marriage that the basis of the grounds for dissolution under the Matrimonial Causes Act-that of matrimonial fault-can be found. The law reflected a community recognition that if one party destroyed the fabric of the marriage by an act of adultery, desertion, cruelty, or some other specified matrimonial offence, the other party should have the right to dissolve the legal tie. Although it was not the language of the law, in fact, in today's terminology, the matrimonial offences were evidence of irreconcilable breakdown and are still used for that purpose in the United Kingdom today. But there was soon a recognition that marriage may irreconcilably break down without the specific guilt of one party and so developed the ground of separation.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Supplementary Assistance for Housing

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., in conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, normally I would raise this subject by way of a question at Question Time but to do so I would have to give too much information at the beginning of the question; so I have chosen to raise the matter in the adjournment debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain changes were made in February of this year to eligibility for supplementary assistance. One change was that tenants who had accommodation in public housing authority buildings and who applied for it after February 1982 were not eligible to receive supplementary assistance. Those who were already in such accommodation prior to 1 February 1982 were not to be disadvantaged and still were able to receive some supplementary assistance, albeit not at the higher rate that was allowed after February 1982.

I would like to ask what happens in a situation like this: Suppose a person is renting a housing commission home-a public authority home-in Queensland, was there prior to February 1982 and is receiving a pension plus supplementary assistance at the old rate. Suppose that person takes a job for a short period but earns only enough so that the person is still eligible for a full pension.

The case that I am thinking of is that a person goes out and works for a certain number of weeks but does not earn beyond the maximum annual rate that would preclude that person from obtaining the full pension. While that person is out working, certainly no supplementary assistance is payable because that person is receiving more than the eligible limit of income.

What I would like to know is this: When that person is no longer earning an income, can that person go back onto supplementary assistance? In other words, there has been a break in the receipt of supplementary assistance; the person is still in a housing commission home; the person was receiving the supplementary assistance prior to gaining some income; can that person then go back onto supplementary assistance or is it regarded as a new case? Because that person is in public authority accommodation, is that person not then eligible for the supplementary assistance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The changes made last February to the supplementary assistance were aimed, firstly, to provide greater assistance to those who paid high private rents and who were therefore seen as being most in need of assistance and, secondly, to remove the effect of double subsidy that applied when people were tenants in State housing commission accommodation-that is, accommodation which is provided under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement at a rigidly controlled rental, usually a maximum of one-fifth of the pension. So there is usually in those cases an effective subsidy probably in the order of $20 a week or more. It does vary from place to place according to the rental value of the house. To avoid the hardship which can be felt-hardship is usually a relative matter-when there is a diminution of income the Government determined to have a no-detriment provision which meant that those already in public housing in receipt of supplementary assistance would continue to receive it, as Senator Colston said this evening, at the old rate and therefore did not suffer a diminution of what is of course a fairly limited income.

SPEECH.PARA: The precise example that Senator Colston has raised is not one that I have had to consider. A comparable example, however, is when a tenant ceases to be a tenant in public housing and then subsequently becomes a tenant in public housing so that there is a break in entitlement for a different reason than the one Senator Colston has put before the Senate tonight. In that circumstance my recollection is that the entitlement to supplementary assistance ceases. I think by way of analogy that the entitlement to supplementary assistance probably ceases also in the case that Senator Colston has put before us. Although I was told that Senator Colston would be speaking on the matter of supplementary assistance I was not sure of the precise point that he wished to raise. I have not considered before the precise point that he has raised. Therefore, I give that as an answer which is subject to confirmation. I will seek that confirmation by examining carefully the rules governing this particular benefit as early as I can tomorrow. I will try to give him a final reply tomorrow.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.6 p.m.
